description:
I stumbled upon the streets of Polk on a dark foggy night and right into the abyss of Royál Oak, it instantly became my enchantment.
This dimly lit of a bar/lounge is a perfect place to unwind.  I am extremely obsessed with the decor of this place, It is absolutely purrrrfect. 
Ambiance-check
Drinks-check 
Service-check 
Payment- cash/card (which is a plus because most bars on Polk are cash only) 
I've yet to check this magical place out on a crowded weekend night.
author: Adrianna P.

description: It's reopened again! Love the dusty vintage decor! It feels more genuine rather than contrived. The bartender is super fun to talk to and is willing to mock up cocktails with and for me! New regular haunt!
author: M U.

description: This bar has a great ambiance and environment to it. The place is filled with old "royal" looking furniture. Although we went on a Friday night, we were just about the only people there. The one complaint I do have is that in the time being of us there, the bartender played the same mash mix up of songs four times in a row.
author: Emma J.

description: Great place to relax and have a lovely drink. Stephanie at the bar was very attentive and entertaining.  Nice atmosphere, love the eclectic decor.   Lovely speakeasy.  Will return, again and again.
author: Patty D.

description:
The hours at the Royal Oak are really undependable.  They're usually not open.  However, when they are open, they have a lot cushy seating to chill.  

The place reminds me of a furniture store that focuses on restoring Victorian chairs with velveteen covers.  It's one of a kind on the sports bar block of Polk Street.
author: Amy J.

description: My new favorite in town! Great service by Stephanie, amazing vibe, great atmosphere,  good prices and selection.
author: Bob H.

description:
Wow, this man must have lost his contact- why else would he awkwardly be reaching onto this chair pushed under the table? Wait, he is wearing glasses!

Guess the reason is because that is where  my North Face jacket was before it was stolen. Sucks to be caught in the act, sir!

Does anyone know this man? (!!!)

Giving the establishment one star, since when I approached them about the theft they called me a liar.
author: Aviva F.

description: Love this place!! Cool laid back vibe. Excellent bartenders that will tailor drinks to their customers. Love that! The kind of place that is rare in San Francisco.
author: Kelsey W.

description: This bar is awesome!! It is a very cool place to hang out with friends!!  The decor is also very cool. They don't make bars like this anymore!!
author: Leonidas G.

description:
Stopped in because we were looking for a chill place for a drink and conversation, and this was the only not-crowded bar (on St Patrick's, no less).  This was the world warning me, and me not listening.

It looked like a nice cocktail bar, but then...
me: "can i get a Sazerak?"
nice bartender: "...sazawhat?"
gf: "uh...do you have a cocktail menu?"
nice bartender: "yea...we keep thinking we should make one of those..."

So, we get our drinks (which were actually pretty good), pay, take a seat.

5 minutes later, the bartender comes over.  "Uh, hey.  The owner's here, and she didn't like your $20 bill.  Do you have another one I can trade you for?"

Yep.  The bar owner had never seen an old-format (1996) bill, and so she thought it wasn't real.  She then sent the bartender over.  To get different money.  He was super nice about it, but wow.

Anyway, this place...
author: Ethan C.

description:
See comment above ! Great place family owned for 40+ years .... Love
Catherine and her staff!!!
author: Anne J.

description:
I don't write many reviews, but I just got home and this needs to be shared. And this is why we don't go here...

I'll give this place a positive on the decor and ambiance. Pretty different vibe in sf, and typically less crowded, which is nice. That's essentially where the positives end. 

Bar service. I'd recommend having more than 1 bartender working at 10pm on a Saturday night. Call it business insights, call it common sense, this is just plain wrong. Waited 12+ mins to order from a reasonably/minimally occupied bar to order 4 beers. Ok, not ideal, but I can deal. 

Here's where I draw the line: Customer service. 

Towards the end of our time at the bar, around 11pm while we were heading to a different bar, my girlfriend starts to feel sick (food poisoning we later found out). She heads to the bathroom to throw up. 

I crack open the door a few minutes later to check on her, since our friends just left for the next bar. I'm greeted by the same unfriendly bartender who served me earlier, explaining to me that she's "watching over my gf", who clearly is sick in one of the stalls with no help while this bartender is putting on making on the other side of the bathroom. Can I come in to check on her or help while there's no other patrons in the bathroom? NO. I'm not allowed, as I clearly hold my girlfriend's purse (not an intruder, clearly only trying to help my girlfriend).

2 seconds later, older lady who works at the bar barges in while I'm slightly holding open the women's bathroom door. Rudely asks me to leave. Ok, I relinquish the door duties, hoping that my girlfriend is ok inside. 2 additional seconds later, a bartender fellow comes up asking what's going on. Immediately eyeballs me, without hesitation, asks for my ID. Now, let me explain, I am 2 weeks from my 30th birthday and look nowhere near resembling a college sophomore. I explain to the fellow that I'm likely older than him (he looks 24), but I oblige and show him my ID. Results in escalated, rude tone, and begins asking a barrage of additional clarification questions about why I'm waiting for my girlfriend and what's going on. I can't recall the details of the exchange, but out of my group of friends, I'm the passive person, and in this instance, he had my blood boiling. 

My girlfriend proceeded to handle things herself OK in the bathroom, and we left immediately thereafter. This was one of the most chill dinner nights I've had with friends in SF in the last few months, and I was really surprised at the direct, rude interactions with multiple staff of the bar. Not once did any of the 3 staff even simply ask if she was OK, or how they could help. 

Long story short, there is a clear and karmic reason that this place is consistently not crowded, not popular, and very likely hemorrhaging money. I do not recommend supporting their business based on morals and ethics.
author: Kyle F.

description:
I was crushed after the Warriors lost last Sunday and forgot to close out the tab I had started earlier in the evening.  I planned to pick up my card after work on Monday when the bar reopened.  At about 3 pm Monday, my credit card company called me as they had noticed suspicious activity on my card.  Someone had run a thousand dollars of charges on my card all around the Bay Area. 

This establishment hires criminals and I will never go there again. Watch out!!!
author: Melanie M.

description:
It's an absolute shame. This bar has so much going for it - beautiful atmosphere, classic fixtures, good drinks, Tiffany lamps, friendly bartenders, and decent beer selection. However, it is all an unfortunate trade off for one major pitfall: THE MUSIC. Not only is the music selection (cheesy dance/trance mixes) horrible, but it is way too loud for the type of atmosphere fostered here. 

To management - keep your image consistent. Everything about your bar follows a great theme, aside from the music. Turn the dial down and try something more laid back and with some substance: Thievery Corporation, Nightmares on Wax, Classic American songbook...anything but the mismatched, blaring garbage currently played.
author: Anil C.

description: Cool spot and I like the vibe.  I stopped in here for a drink after dinner and was having a great time with my date.  I rated it two stars because I ended up ordering a beer that was flat, but the bartender didn't believe me.  She told me she wasn't a beer drinker and that she would take my word for it but when I ordered something else she charged me full price.  I thought it was standard to replace a flat beer with a different beer for no charge but apparently not here.  Too bad, but still a place worth checking out.
author: Nathan F.

description:
The Polk Street Bars are great for a pub crawl!  If you plan on stumbling into anywhere for dancing this is a great place to go to!  

i wouldn't say it's the best, but it gets the job done if you just want to have a fairly decently open dance floor to dance the night away.

Generallly, they've played top 40 and hip hop the times I've been around.  Good music for me to groove to!
author: Michelle T.

description: Absolutely the worst service I've ever had. Waited 40 minutes for 1 beer from a drunk bartender. Ordered 5 times and waited so long. Busy bar, terrible service. I can't even believe they would hire someone that would be drunk to serve me beer? Coming from out of town to come to SF and can't believe it's been this inconvenient at this establishment.
author: Kastania C.

description:
What a hip bar with fancy lights in the Tender-Marina.  I never new this was here and with a name like Royal Oak I can't say I was thrilled to attend.  Upon walking up to this spot I realized the lights were the main draw in catching my attention.  The music was a mix of hip-hop and house with good beats throughout the night.  The crowd wasn't very mixed in the since that you could tell every white Marina individual who has ever felt out of place by their community has come forth in hordes to show their faces.

Grab a couch and you'll be surprised at the sights you see while sipping on decently priced drinks.  Have fun.  Relax.
author: Kevin J.

description:
This is a terrible bar. If it were on the show Bar Rescue, Jon Taffer would tear it apart. The bartender was drunk. Took forever to take my drink order. After she finally took it, she started unloading the dishwasher and taking other drink orders. Then she comes back to me realizing she screwed up and asked for my order again. Then when I received my drinks she made the wrong ones. Gave me a totally wrong drink (all I asked for was a whiskey ginger). She hands me a bill for the drinks that seemed like she made it up on the spot. My credit card got passed around to three different people behind the bar and took five minutes before it finally got back to me. The bar was not that busy and they still screwed up. 

Oh and the bathroom had a pool of piss on the floor from a broken toilet. No one cleaned it up all night. 

There are much better bars in the area.
author: Taylor W.

description: The decor is what drew me in, the complete lack of service is what drove me away. I arrived around 10 pm on a Friday night, the place was close to empty. I tried to order a beer but was told they had run out so I ordered a different one. 10 minutes later when I still had no beer in my hand I walked out.
author: Danielle M.

description: Awesome low light, old-world atmosphere, strong and fairly-priced drinks, and polite bartenders and bouncers. My friends and I only had a great time here, even though the music wasn't great it was much better than most of the surrounding bars. I really like the place and it's probably the coolest bar in the Russian Hill neighborhood on Polk street.
author: Dominic B.

description: This place is awesome! The drinks are cheap and the bartender is nice. Especially the the one beer + shot for 5$ is worth mentioning. The beer selection is good. The interior looks like a mash up of 70s disco and 30s Tea Room furniture with a splash of 80s lights. The music was alright when we were there.
author: Shit H.

description:
After a hard day of stealing Inca gold, running from giant sized boulders, and general all around swashbuckling adventure, I like to kick back with a whiskey ginger ale in the confines of the dimly lit Royal.

The decor allows me to live out my 1930s well traveled adventurer fantasy with hot bartenders and awesome drink specials to boot.

The only thing that could make this place cooler would be a badass tiger statue containing a hidden lever that automatically refills my glass with DRANK.
author: Sam J.

description:
ATMOSPHERE:
Kinda pale in comparison to its neighboring bars. Not bad place to chill and catchup with friends over a beer tho I suppose. 

10.17.13
author: Angela L.

description:
Two stars for the couches and ambience.

The bartenders were impossibly rude. They served all the drinks with attitude. At ten oclock they had the audacity to tell us to leave, because they got to go home when the last customers left. The really ought to be fired.
author: Christina D.

description:
The music absolutely ruins this place.

Because other than that it's wonderful. It's one of the few places where you can actually sit down and have a conversation with people in Russian Hill. The antique seating is amazing, the lighting is great, the ambiance is right on.

But they always play these terribly awful dance/trance/house mashups that are dated, cheezy and totally wrong for the bar's overall atmosphere. If I want to dance I'll go to Bullitt or Rouge. You can't dance with 50 antique couches filling the bar. It's physically impossible.

If the owners of this read this review PLEASE change your music lineup during the week. I love your bar, it's right down the street from me, but the music is just awful.

Play some classic crooner music, Motown hits, classic hip hop, indie, acoustic, ANYTHING other than what you're playing.

Hell, get a jukebox and make some money. But for God's sake...do something because I really, really want to hang out in your bar without feeling like my ears are going to puke.

Two stars because the decor and seating of the place is fantastic but the music makes me suicidal.
author: Corbin C.

description:
The atmosphere is fantastic, everything else is pretty average. 

This is not a bar I go to because of their fabulous cocktails, or super awesome bartenders, yet it is one of the places I like best on this area of polk. The dimly lit stained glass lamps, the comfortable old (yet classy) couches, and the fact that its never SUPER packed (like most places in this area), make it a recommended stop. 

They take cash or card, I have had some good bartenders and some ok ones, the drinks are not better or stronger than anywhere else, but very on par. If you're just looking for a cool ambiance and a place you can sit down with a group and enjoy a few drinks, this is your spot.
author: Jess K.

description:
This place is nice.  The bartender is cool.  The decor is what I call "stuck-up seductive."  They have some flat screens showing either sports or music videos, which is fine, but what I don't understand is why there is a giant light fixture hanging immediately IN FRONT OF the tv at the bar.  Logic was missing the day either one was installed, apparently.

They need to serve some food or at least some munchies.
author: Jess H.

description: Cool bar in an area with LOTS of choices. The drinks were prepared with care and are inexpensive for SF. I had the cucumber tonic and the wife had a gimlet. Cool Bartender, thanks Furio!!!
author: Joe K.

description: Great place. Well made beverages! Really cute bar and on the weeknights, there aren't any douche bags :) Thank you, Mike!
author: Disco B.

description: This place is a fantastic place to chill with friends. One of my favorite places on this side of town. And the people who work here are really awesome and friendly :)
author: Megan L.

description: I only pop in from time to time, but the staff is always a friendly bunch. The classy decore is inviting and definitely a place to share a drink with a friend or a date. The bathroom is also very clean which is always a plus.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
So glad we spotted this gem since we were silently getting kicked out of nick's crispy tacos in the middle of watching the warriors game on wednesday. -___-
Walked down the street and found this semi-empty bar with the game on the tv; so of course we barged right in and sat close to the tv. 
They had a special going on which was get one of their selected beers (i got a corona & my bf got a Heineken) plus a shot. Beer + shot = $5??!! What a deal! And to top it off, the warriors beat the spurs! Woot woot!!
I didn't even notice the decor in the bar until after the game. It reminded me of the roaring 20's, and felt the need to watch the Great Gatsby coming out soon. Lol..
At least there's plenty of seats and tables and everybody to get all cozy. 
I'd probably come here again...
author: Navy C.

description: Could be a great place, if they didn't hire DRUG ADDICTS. Saw one of the bartenders doing Coke in the bathroom. She should be fired- for managements reference it was a girl with short brown hair.
author: Sarah R.

description: Amazing service. Was the Victoria's 2nd night and went above and beyond to make everyone happy. Extremely hard to do in this city and when you are in your own. I will recommend and come return! Thanks Victoria!
author: S C.

description:
I can't quite figure out if this place is a club or a bar... the place is set up to be a bar with tables and chairs and booths everywhere for you to sit and hang out, but they play blazing music that causes everyone to dance up in between the tables and empty aisles making the whole experience really awkward because someone is hip thrusting next to you while you're sitting. 

Coming here on a Saturday Night at 11pm means the place is completely packed, but upside is eventually you'll find your bar niche for the night, the bartenders are pretty nice - i got a drink without a problem, so sit back and get cozy with your friends because that's the only way you'll be able to hear them.
author: Christine B.

description: Im a fan - I just moved into the neighborhood and pass by during the day and will love it here I just know it!!!
author: Page D.

description:
:-) I like the atmosphere of this place: decorations in tones of dark woods and reds, velvet "antique" couches that give you the feeling you're hanging out in someone's living room back in time, live and  healthy looking plants, big windows... It can be quiet during the week, which is what I prefer, but very busy on weekends!
Service has always been good to me. The bartender Briana is a sweetie!
Only draw back for me is the bathroon, it needs a little TLC...
author: Luci P.

description:
Super fancy lounge with sticky floors and good beers on tap. This place surely has an identity crisis. Are you a bar? VIP lounge? 

The sticky floors were quite distracting, but you hardly notice after a couple of drinks and meeting a couple of strangers. Service was quick - No BS from the bartenders and no attitude. 

We came on a Friday night and there was no cover. A nice save, since a few bars in the area already had a cover. The crowd was really chill and we actually met some pretty cool people. That's a rarity in SF! 

Good crowd. Chill bar. Comfy seats. Reasonable drink prices. Count us in for return-sies!
author: Mar A.

description:
Yea this place has a misdirected vibe.

Usually I love places with seating, of which they definitely have plenty accomodating our group of about 18. It was just SO freaking loud in there that a friend and I felt like our neck muscles were sore from all the screaming to communicate with people. Really not a pleasant way to wake up.

They should figure out if they are trying to be a bar/lounge or a club and tailor the space on way or the other. Probably won't be back.
author: Raina B.

description:
This is my fave neighbor go-to. I love the old funky grandmother's living room vibe it's got with the gorgeous wood, tiffany's lamps everywhere and mirrors (ok, the tiger is weird, but i'm sure there's a back story for it). They've got a really friendly staff and even though it gets annoyingly packed at times, for the most part it's a good amount of people and isn't too hard to snag a couch and table spot. 
Cash only which can be a bummer if you aren't ready for it, but it also makes (at least me) way less likely to wake up the next morning wondering how many drinks I actually had where all my money went.
author: Audrey V.

description:
I'm currently at the bar so I can provide a realtime simulated experience for you, the future satisfied customers.

When your foot first touches the unkept burgundy carpet, your nostrils will be pleasantly kissed by the aromatic candles cluttering the bar shelves.  

Now open your eyes.  The 15 Tiffany chandeliers (shan-del-ee-aye for you classy types) glowing softly overhead and the Victorian furnishings will make you feel like it's high tea at grandma's after Sunday service, except you're here to get drunk, not talk about who's recently courting Ms. Mary Louise - that skank.

I would have given this place 5 stars if it weren't for the shitty caca bathrooms.  Imagine being on a 14 hour flight with one lavatory and you are the very last person to take a shit. Think of a solitary confinement chamber in Russia without toilet paper.  Or, a raccoon who got himself stuck in a sewage line.

Speaking of butt stuff - Sasha.  OMG (that is the first time I've used that acronym) she has a nice ass.

Wake up......Go to Royal Oak.
author: Chris B.

description: Finally went here after all these wondering what it was like - curiosity is quenched.  Ehh...it was all right.  I was confused by the ambiance - old-style Victorian looking furniture, palm trees, sports TV playing in the background and heavy base music too loud to talk over.  Ahhh...must be getting old.  We only stayed for 5 minutes tops, wasn't too keen.
author: Maile N.

description:
Cute little spot, bar hopped to this spot late NYE.  It was really crowded and I didn't get a chance to really check it out but I do recall the smell of vomit... It WAS NYE after all.

Good music but I'll need another visit before I add any more stars.
author: Cynthia V.

description:
we weren't in here for very long, but in short, it was a huge sausage fest of the kinds of guys i'm not into.  now i usually don't mind sausage fests (obviously), and i don't mean to sound like i'm in love with myself, but people just wouldn't stop staring.  probably because we were the only girls there.  the people were just so awkward about it... they could have used a little more discretion.

there were some foreign guys there with stickers on their faces too.  so weird... you may be european, but you can't get away with everything!!
author: Jennifer L.

description: it was nice and quiet.  rare for this neighborhood.  Great bar if you can find a seat
author: David L.

description:
Likes: the colored lights, the couches and oak tables, plus we weren't carded to enter, only for purchases

Dislikes:
author: Karen M.

description: If you're going to go here, don't go later than ten. We got a couch in the center, but by 11, the place was too crowded and under staffed. Two bar keeps, one of which was slow and drunk. We has two rounds over two hours because I spent 30 minutes ordering the second. Place had style and music was good, which brought my rating up from 2.
author: Tim L.

description: Comfortable couches, living room style. Dim lit room. The bartender is nice. Loud music, but you can still talk over the music. The vibe depends on the type of music being played. When we walked into the bar/lounge there was hard core rap music on, which I wasn't a fan. So I asked the bartender if we could change up the music, and she happily changed it to house music. Much better. Thanks!!
author: Karen S.

description: Stumbled upon this bar while making our way through the Blues Festival on Polk St on a Sunday afternoon.  The niners were playing, so naturally we had to find a place to watch the game once we had our fill of blues music.  What reeled us into the Royal Oak was the beer + shot special for $5.  The list of beers for the special included some of my go-to's; the shot was either Jameson or a fireball.  Decent options of poison for the price.  We sat at the bar, our view of the TV somewhat obstructed by a huge chandelier that hung right in front of it.  Still, we were able to enjoy the game and got a nice afternoon buzz from a couple beers and fireball shots.
author: Thi D.

description:
I'm confused, is this place supposed to be a lounge? bar? or club? 
Based on the cheap drinks and bartender's attitude, I'd say it started off as a laid back bar, but then the additions came. The seating area is filled with velvet chairs, old world couches and mismatched tables, almost got a coffee house vibe to it, so you'd think it's a lounge or sit-down bar. But there is no way to have a conversation due to the BLARING club music. Oh, and there are palm trees and neon lights mixed in with the velvet couches... Kind of feels like the owner's too many ideas of what he wants this establishment to be and can't choose one, so he combined them all. Wasn't a bad experience, just weird, prob won't be back.
author: Claudia Z.

description:
It's a good change-of-pace from your typical Russian Hill-side Polk Street experience, but there's this one bartender there who consistently gives me sass.

On one specific visit, this bartender (henceforth to be known as OTLD - "Overly Tall and Lanky Dude") offered me a free drink. Given our tenuous relationship, I was taken aback by what appeared to be a peace offering. Could it be that OTLD was turning a new leaf and our previous troubles were going to be water under the bridge?

Nope.

As I was cocking my head back to take the shot as dramatically as possible (false bravado in an attempt to show appreciation), I instinctively asked what it was I was about to drink. The answer?

OTLD: "I don't know."

Me: "Huh? What do you mean you don't know?"

OTLD: "I mean, I don't know."

Me: "Dude, you're the bartender. How can you not know what you're pouring?"

OTLD: "I didn't pour it. [The drink] has just been sitting here for awhile, no one's drinking it, and [the other bartender] and I can't figure out what it is."

Me: "......................."

...and the grudge continues.
author: Leo K.

description: Have you been to a better fern bar?  It's been in the family for decades now and is great little escape... where else to get lost in a corner with a drink and some friends or double dates... and as of recent they have a great new craft beer from a couple hundred year old german brewery... It was delicious.. micro bubbles...
author: Adam O.

description: Awesome place! I loved it and they definitely take card. Beautiful bar and great drinks!
author: Ashlee H.

description: Was my first time here over the weekend, and I was impressed! The ambiance was really cool! I particularly liked the fact that the patrons were all different ages. From 20's to young professionals in their 30's to 50 year olds, everyone was getting their drink on. Aside from the main bar area, they had big round tables and booths you could sit in. They looked pretty comfortable. We stayed at the bar to people watch. I only drank beer, so I can't really comment on how well they mix drinks, but I do know if you want a glass of wine, this is not the place to come. My friend wanted a glass of white wine and there was only one Chardonnay option for $12. Anyway, the name "Royal Oak," is truly fitting and I'm looking forward to returning.
author: Kelsey K.

description: Cool little bar. Very laid back in a part of town where it's hard to find a laid back bar. Nice furniture, as well. The only downside is that they close before 2.
author: Zach H.

description:
Cozy waterhole in Russian Hill.  3.5 stars

Cost to worth it ratio: 3.5

Highlights:
- Maroon walls
- Foliage
- Stained glass lampshades
- Dark ambiance
- Small
- Inventive bartender: I asked for a cocktail using vodka and not sweet and got some unique ones

Lowlights:
- Cash only

Brings back memories--we used to frequent this place a lot in our post college all of us were single party days so it has that nostalgia quality going for it and I'll stop in time and time again for a drink.
author: Eve K.

description:
Uh, what? Sorry, I can't hear you. My ears are still ringing from the fist-pumping music that was BLARING when I went to Royal Oak on Friday night. Which would be great if this place was actually a club... but it's not. It's a sit-down bar. WHERE YOU ARE SUPPOSED TO HEAR PEOPLE TALK. 

It's too bad, really, because the sit-down areas are pretty neat. Plush, vintage couches and high-backed antique chairs everywhere, stained-glass lamps, that sort of thing. Kind of like if someone inherited a bunch of stuff from an old relative and put it all in one room. But the eclectic decor is pretty much the only redeeming quality about this place; my whiskey sour was poorly mixed and too expensive, I could barely hear my four other friends who were sitting right next to me, and--here's the kicker--the TVs were playing The O'Reilly Factor. Disgusting.
author: Stefanie L.

description: Where did they get their couches?  My best guess is the set of Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil.  Or the fantasia of Truman Capote.  Or maybe the mansion of a Southern Belle that escaped to live on Nob Hill after her husband struck it rich selling supplies to miners during the Gold Rush.  Regardless, I dig. Not your $7 well drink price.  Come now, that's inflation.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
I didn't hate it here.  Less douchy than a lot of nearby bars.  I didn't say no douchy.

Cash only - that's douchy.  Fuck all, there goes my hidden $20.
author: Meg W.

description:
This place is nice. I like the red decor and palms. They play good music. I almost wish they had a dance floor, I liked the music that much. It doesn't get overly crowded and we were able to find seats easily.

The bathrooms on the other hand, that's a different story. Two of the lights were out over the toilets, and it was dark as night in each stall. Couldn't see a damn thing.
author: Patricia Y.

description:
I've (somewhat surprisingly) had some fabulous times at the Royal Oak. If you want a bar where you might be able to sit down on Polk Street, I think the Royal Oak is one of your best options. It's cash only which can be advantageous if only the boys you are with are carrying cash and they want to buy you beverages ;) Some memorable times:

- started friend's birthday bar crawl here; one of our friends created the "Summer hairdo" of our friend out of cardboard so that we could all sport Summer's bob!
- I really wanted a mojito but they were out of mint so my friend ran across to the market across the street, bought fresh mint, and they prepared a great mojito for me with this mint!
- I got bet $30 that I wouldn't drink a mixed cocktail including beer, cosmo (not sure whose it was...), etc... I willingly accepted the bet, got several cheers, and the rest of my night was paid for
- we took over a huge table and played several dice games with the dice you can borrow from the bar

Overall, great times are to be had at the Royal Oak! During the week, it tends to be a pretty chill, living-room-ish bar but it gets much more hopping on the weekends...
author: Meghan P.

description: Came here on a Tuesday night and had a pleasant time. It wasn't too loud or crowded- I could have a conversation with my friends without screaming over the music. The bar has a really nice atmosphere- its more of a cross between a bar and a lounge actually. Old fashioned sofas and Tiffany lamps give the Royal Oak the charming air of a 1920s parlour. Drinks are reasonably priced. I would definitely come back here when I'm in San Francisco next because of the cool atmosphere. I love bars that don't feel like bars.
author: Yoshi K.

description:
This place is GREAT! It really has everything a bar on Polk should have. Great music, strong and CHEAP drinks and the staff is ridiculously friendly. The manager of the place really cares about making it a top notch bar, so he's been making improvements to the place almost daily. They just put in a few new bar lights that really tie everything in. Our bartender Stefani makes the best drinks in town, hands down...solid gold...so good this place should be a club.

If you're looking for a good place to grab some drinks mid-week, this is the place to do it. We went on a Wednesday and there was a good crowd for being in the middle of the work week.
author: A V.

description:
This bar has a cozy ambiance, the lighting is dim and the seating includes comfy couches, and upolherstered chairs that feel like velvet.  Came with 2 friends on a Saturday night around 9 pm and we sat at the bar.  Bartender took our drink order and she suggested to us the special that ended at 10pm: Beer and shot for $5.  We all decided to take up the special, Stella and fireball shot for $5, not bad for a Saturday night.  The bartender was nice enough to chill the shots.  

This is nice, but I came at an early time so I do not know how rowdy or lively the crowd will get,  I would come back again to get a quick drink soley for the comfy seats and hopefully next time I come back they will have the beer and shot special.
author: Linda C.

description:
I have been living in San Francisco for ten years now. I know this place like the back of my hand. If you are looking for a very cool old school SF bar lounge then check out The Royal Oak.

The place is located in Russian Hill. The outside looks somewhat mysterious in a 1979 type of way. When you walk in the slight red glow and the lush fern ambiance sets in and all of a sudden you think to your self wow a drink sounds great. Then things get good. 

A hot girl bartender will walk up, smile and ask what you want to drink. That's always my favorite part. The drink I'm talking about ;-) but yes the girls that work there are always attractive and really add to the lure of the place. 

So, yes, I highly recommend The Royal Oak. In my ten years of hanging out there from time to time I must say, the place is a lot of fun and has a lot of San Francisco character. 

P.S. - And by the way, what is up with all the haters on this site? I cant even count the number of times people bitched about the cash bar on here. Look if spending some cash on some drinks is a problem then find something else to do.
author: Thor H.

description:
Laid back bar.

Funky decor. The place is decorated like your grandmothers ancient living room. Red velvet couches etc

Good place to talk with friends and just relax.

The crowd here is late 20s to 30s for the most part
author: James B.

description:
so this bar has been on my list for a while, hence I would always pass by during the day, etc.. 

Finally made it in, and the decor lived up to my expectations super cute plush sofas, chandeliers, stain glass windows..HOWEVER, the mood was completely KILLED by the top 40 music. It really should've been jazz, or instrumental, anything but what they were playing. I suppose it could have been worse, but it could have been so much better! I also, think it could loose the T.V's I mean it's not a sports bar... 

Minus the music, I liked how it was not too crowded. I was able to sit at the bar with out people pushing me over for drinks.
author: Kay J.

description:
So I'm obviously not a Russian Hill person and Royal Oak is really not my scene. 

But I still liked this red velvet hip hop lounge, and it's impressive collection of stained-glass light fixtures. 

The bartender got my order wrong, but collins to tonic is a fair mistake in a loud bar and not that big of a deal so she still left me with a favorable impression.  

It certainly helps in forgiving these mistakes that I am not anticipating having to go back.
author: Luke M.

description: What a cool little pub. Old antiques and Chandalers and good music.
author: Tom B.

description:
This bar confuses me. They try to be upscale and classy.. and then all of a sudden at 10PM a DJ walks in and sets up and starts spinning hits from the 90s? I think this bar is having an identity crisis,.

I also didn't appreciate the fact that my wine glass had lipstick marks all over it and smelled like mold. And the fact that I paid $12 for it pissed me off even more... So much so that I just drank out of my moldy used glass with resentment knowing that I'd never step foot in here again.

The crowd is lame too..
author: Kathy S.

description: Fun place, went in to avoid all the other nearby bars/pubs that were blasting sporting events.  The staff were fun and we stayed at the bar all night.  We tried to go back the next couple nights but they were closed, which was sad.  But one fun night is all it took to make for a memorable experience!
author: Ben J.

description:
I had a horrible experience at this bar this past Saturday night out with two other friends, and wanted to pass along all the absurdity so that no one else would get screwed in the same way.  

Ordered a single round of drinks from one of the two pleasant but inebriated bartenders, both girls.  Left my card and sat down.  When I returned to close out my card and move on 25 min later, I was presented with a bill for $69, and this is after the bartender 'kindly' comp'd two drinks 'because my tab was so high'.  WTF?!? One round, $69+ for three people??  'Please show me my tab, you must have had someone else put drinks on it.'  Then it gets ugly, 'see the Mexican guy over there?  He just threw out all the paperwork, so there is none to show you'  Seriously??  Then I got a bunch of lies and  false and contradictory statements from the bartender, who finished by insulting me, told me it was my fault and too bad.  The door guy, Rick, while kind was inept and had no information or authority to help in any fashion, even though he seemed to believe he could.  Didn't even have a good phone number to call a manager or owner about this whole issue.  I work in and around the nightlife industry here in the City, and call multiple owners both friends and business associates.  Stunned that this would happen at any place, but to hear the doorman brag about the 'reputation' of this quality establishment, you would think that they would have had some other way to deal with these problems.  No, they don't.  I literally feel like this girl reached into my pocket and stole from me, and her response was the worst, most cliche'd 'Marina girl' response you could imagine.  Entitled, snotty, flat out lied, and then went back to drinking shots and flirting with the guys at the end of the bar.  I am only happy they are not my employees.  Worst. Bar. Ever.  On Polk, so many options, try to pick a place where the drunk girls are in front of the bar, not behind it, that way you control your $$, not the bar.
author: A K.

description:
I want to hate this place.  I really do.  I tried to walk out and go to other nearby places constantly but it kept sucking me back in.  Curses!

Royal Oak embodies almost everything I hate about going out.  Gorilla-sized security guards (but they're so nice!) gaudy horrible furniture (ok, its classy)  and mixed table/bar food service (that's priced so right!) and people way too well dressed and too good at dancing (that make an awesome party). This review is a failure to accept that the mainstream got it so right here -- so right that I couldn't help enjoy myself despite my ridiculous mental problems and barhopping criteria.

But wait, I have more complaints that I can't cash!

The lights are too bright and there's an awkward divider which eliminates the space for a dance floor so people will dance behind the bar.  If the dancing gets good (and it does, dammit!) the bar becomes an impenetrable fortress and you'll have to take a tour to get to the other side.  This would be bad in most cases except for the fact that everyone is so good looking in here.  Easily the most attractive crowd of people I've seen since I've been here.  Dammit!

Death to the demoness Allegra Gellar,for the drinks are the bomb!

I want to dislike this place, but I can't.  I refuse to give in though.  I don't plan on going back any time soon, but I'll be dragged there by circumstance and I'll surely enjoy it for hours again.  Curses, I say!
author: niero g.

description: If youre a donald trump supporter then this place is for you.  Complete with racism and bats to hit people over the head with.  Sounds like a good time.
author: Ferdinand B.

description:
Ahhh..the fern bar....It's a decent neighborhood bar on week nights....also responsible for many pairs of beer goggles I've collected over the years..
Something about their old couches though...Each time I go there I feel like I need to de-sanitize my clothes after....
author: Mimi T.

description:
I really want this to be my neighborhood bar that I can go to on like a Tuesday - I live a block away.  So much potential... I used to come here all the time in my mid-20s - maybe I'm just older and lamer and married?  I dig the retro decor, great beer selection, respect that it's old-skool cash only, bartenders are cool.  

But the music KILLS me.  Dude - you can't play "untz untz" pseudo DJ'd music meant for Mr. Smiths or Rogue when you have NO DANCE SPACE.  It's too loud, too obnoxious, and meant for too many hoochy mammas.  Stick to something old school, maybe a juke box would help.  

Yet I keep going back... probably bc it's decent before 9pm before the bouncer shows up and the redick music starts.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Ahhhh what can I say... well a lot! I hate this place. No, I dont "want" to hate this place, I absolutely hate this place. I have never felt so pissed after going to a bar, but Royal Oak was sure to provide me with that experience.

The drinks here suck. And thats not to say the alcohol sucks, no, the freakin bartenders do not know how to make a drink. Look, Im a young guy, and when I go to a bar, I want to get drunk if not nearly so. So I ordered a freaking AMF (my clubers know this drink). You expect it to make you go adios! Not this drink my friends. It was the sweetest, bluest, adios mutha effer I ever tasted/seen! Sickening. After receiving a sugar headache from the first one, I asked for another, but told the bartender to please make it stronger. What do I get, the exact same nasty, sweet drink. Then she made me pay $7 dollars for a shot because I said it wasnt strong enough. That was just the beginning. 

When its time to go, the clueless bartender tells me my card is declined. HMMMMM, I say, Ive got plenty of money on my card, and even if I didnt, the bank would just overdraft my as$. So I check my bank account on my phone, and low and behold, this chick has charged my card 6 times!!!! Literally, 6 times! Of course the card wont go through, they think you're robbing me! Luckily I got it sorted out with my bank, but having that money help up for almost a week is no fun in any situation.

Overall, this place sucks! A bunch of yuppie pricks who ultimately cant make drinks. I will say one good thing, hence the one star. One of the hostess was as nice and accommodating as she could possibly be in such a lacking place, and for that I thank her. She was the only positive here and should find a better place to work. Nuff said!
author: William H.

description:
Great neighborhood bar to relax and enjoy a beverage after a longgggg day!

Start or end your night here, and kick-back with the locals!
author: Kristian P.

description:
The atmosphere provides something lacking in this neighborhood, which is "lounge."  The green ferns and banana leaves are a fresh contrast to the chandelier-like light fixtures, maroon walls, and velour covered arm chairs and love seats.    

PROS:
-Vibe/atmosphere/theme.
-Different from local bars.
-Furniture.
-Novelty.

CONS: 
-Cash only is lame.
The quality of the furniture here is something to be desired.
-50% of the time, the bartenders are retarded.
author: Ryan T.

description:
I'm going to preface this review with this statement. I hate Wrigleyville bars. I hate Wrigleyville, period. You have to drag me, kicking and screaming to this area of town...
This is the only bar in the area that I don't mind going to, and usually it's a pre-drink or post-drink when going out to eat at Cozy Noodle...the only restaurant that I like in Wrigley. The owner is a sweetheart and the main reason I love this place. Not sure how crazy it is on the weekend, but during the week you can chill in the back room and avoid all the d-bags doing yeager bombs and have a nice convo.
author: Mia M.

description: Wow. Did the neighborhood change? I used to visit this place back in the day and it was much different. Now - loud bass music on the annoying side. The kind of music you'd expect at a dance club. Too loud to have a conversation yet the ambiance and setting (comfy couches) are best suited for a relaxing piano music kind of place. No room to dance. So I don't get it. And the bartenders were anything but friendly and accomodating. We were there early on a Friday night (7pm) and we were the only ones there. Hmmm. Anyway, I would not go back UNLESS the music were different. Then I would go a lot.
author: M D.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and I really wish somebody would buy this place and fix it up so it could live up to it's potential. There's reasons why all the bars in the area are packed and hardly anybody inside Royal Oak

Problems: 
-cash bar only (really??.. no really?? this is 2009) 
-bartenders are never friendly
-drinks are pricey, even for russian hill
author: Dave T.

description: Fun hipster bar with retro couches, chandeliers and a lot of locals. Great spot to meet up with a bunch of people to either begin or end your evening. Pull up a seat, grab a beer (remember cash!) and you're good to go.
author: Alie A.

description: This is one of my favorite bars on Polk. It's especially good on a not so busy  night where you can grab a seat at the big round table with a group of friends. I have never seen this place too packed though, and you can usually find a spot to sit if you keep your eyes peeled. Staff is friendly, and they clean the place up pretty well. Sometimes too well. I have had a drink or two gone missing when I wasn't finished with it yet-- oh well. A random plus, they have glow in the dark straws. Pretty darn amazing.
author: Ashley D.

description:
We came here as a second choice due to the lack of space to move next door at bullet (and the girl hurling). 

On the positive side:
- love the plants
- random red lighting
- quality people watching
- retro couches to make you laugh
- decently strong drinks

On the negative end:
- cash only (seriously?)
author: Sarah T.

description: Been there a couple times. Reminds me of a red jungle. They have weird trees and plants and the setting is red so hence the red jungle. Can get crowded on the weekends and the music is cool. Try it out if you're ever on Polk.
author: Lisa Z.

description:
I always used to walk by this place and thought it looked intriguing, but it would invariably be closed.  Finally, one day we were walking home and the doors were open!  Hurray!

Comfortable, cozy, vintage decor.  Plush velvety sofas, darkened mirrors, lots of weathered gilt trim and potted palms and ferns separating the seating areas.  I really enjoyed just sitting back, sipping my drink, and letting the world pass by in a place where it looks like time has stopped.  

Great seating areas for large groups and lots of room early-ish on a Saturday evening.  Good place to stop after Rouge/Nick's Crispy Tacos if you still haven't had enough red velvet action.
author: Jaimie M.

description: good hip hop music and not packed on a thursday. the service on the other hand can use allot of improving. the bartendar forgot what we ordered twice. then when i wanted to close my tab she came over twice to ask my name and then for the third time wanted to know if i wanted to close my tab?? omg frustrating! plus she neglected to tell us they only had diet coke!
author: Vanny R.

description:
I took away a star because of my experience here last Monday night (the night of our WORLD SERIES WIN!!!).
Royal Oak was seriously the only bar that wasn't packed to the gills, so we went in to grab a shot of tequila in celebration. The girl behind the bar literally wouldn't even look at us-- she stood on the opposite end of the bar chatting with her friends. I was standing with about three other groups who also wanted a drink, all of us ended up leaving. 
You would think the bartender would be happy about making tips on this busy weekday, especially because everyone was in such a wonderful mood. She was honestly so rude, she didn't deserve our money.
author: Kenzie P.

description:
Way too loud, way too crowded, way too expensive.

Went on a busy Friday night. Not at all my scene, slumming it Marina folk. 

Ambiance, cool.  Drink, awful, a whiskey sour is NOT made with orange juice. Music, god awful.

The music was way, way, way to loud for a bar that doesn't also have dancing. Also, it was this weird house music. Horrible, just horrible.

That being said, I would come here again, on a weekday during the day. I think it would be a great hang out on a cold rainy Tuesday afternoon, sitting on a cushy Victorian settee with a beer. 

But a hang out bar it is not.
author: Alexa B.

description:
Royal Oak is a decent place to grab a drink on Polk St. and since it's not too far of a walk from some Marina places it's a good destination if you're in the Marina and looking for a change of pace. They have Chimay on tap, which I love and the bartender made a mean Marker's Mark manhattan.

There is plenty of seating so this is also a good option if you're with a group earlier in the evening and looking for a place to camp out at. Music was entertaining the night I was there but be warned, it can get crowded on prime nights so if you need a seat go early.
author: Bryan B.

description:
The owners don't hire male bartenders because their lunatic son might hurt them.  Seriously.

I used to love this bar, but after tonight I will never go there again.  Furthermore, I am scared for the bartenders and the female patronage as long as they let their son on the property.  The usually tranquil environment was ruined this evening as the owner's son smashed up the priceless, original turn-of-the century pieces, screaming about how he was going to kill everyone while he wore a KKK outfit.

You might think that sounds extreme or maybe even comical, but put yourself in the situation.  We were scared girls who hadn't spoken to him, trapped in a corner while he threw our table and screamed how he was going to kill all of the police because he was "Federal." The owner did nothing, merely took her time removing him from the property.

He shouldn't be allowed there.  It was seriously the scariest situation I have ever experienced in a bar.  This place should be stripped of their liquor license until he is locked into a mental ward.

People who pace back and forth, talking to themselves while rocking are not good barstaff-- I don't care who's son he might be, he is dangerous.

Before I used to love relaxing there, enjoying the beautiful and original decor of this historic, former speakeasy, while sipping great-priced scotch-- never again!

Don't go there-- it's not worth being hurt.  Seriously disturbing!!  I pity the ever-changing barstaff!  The owners should consider what would happen should anyone be seriously hurt, or worse-- killed.  It will be on their conscience.
author: Tracy B.

description:
RECENT UPDATE: i really missed this place so recently came back and GOOD NEWS, that mean old bartender is gone! yeah! the allure of royal oak is first of all, such a great location in russian hill. then you've got all thoes plants, and those big massive round tables and mirrors everywhere. i'm happy to report the royal oak is back on my favorites list again : )

i almost forgot about this place... its really not one of my favorites on polk st. i love the huge round tables and mirrors everywhere but i had the worst service from one of the female bartenders. i had my money on the counter, did the 'maintain eye contact' thing and she merely glanced at me and then went on the help about 4 different guys (who walked up AFTER me) before finally coming down to my end. i even went so far as to smile at her but got nothing but attitude back. i am usually very patient with bartenders (as i know they get busy) but this one left me so pissed-off i vowed to never go back. the first time ever i did not leave a tip-- it was that bad. still havent't been back.
author: Michelle I.

description:
I have to say I like this place a lot more than general consensus.  It has a very attractive ambiance and since most people can't seem to remember the name I'm often describing it as either: "the plush red bar" or "fern bar."  

On week nights it's one of the true lounges in the city; easy to get a drink with friends and hear each other talk.  The bartenders are friendly and sweet enough to turn down the music to a reasonable volume (which elsewhere seems to be the cardinal sin of drinking in SF).   Weekends the place tries to transform into a club and I don't find it to be as consistently enjoyable, but if that's your thing... go for it.

On my last visit (random Monday night) the bartender drawled out a very friendly "what can I get you darlin'?" every time I approached and it was thoroughly charming.  She also mixed up a killer Red Headed Slut for my buddy who'd just turned 21.

So, keeping in mind that I really like this place the other reviewers do have some legitimate complaints which I offer here as constructive criticism (fix these and the place would rock):  

1)  the bar is schizophrenic about credit cards... sometimes they'll let you charge one, sometimes you can give one but only to hold a tab you'll have to close with cash... sometimes they just blink at you.  It's not the mission... you should take credit. 

2)  The place is a bit pricey compared to its neighbors.  I actually think well drinks are sometimes accidentally charged as shelf drinks exacerbating this, but haven't had that issue with beer.  

3) Minor nitpick: the bar is starting to show its age.  Some of the seating could use attention (new upholster or more stuffing).

Enjoy!
author: David K.

description:
I have a couple problems with this place:

1) The seating that looks so enticing when you walk in is really just an illusion. They are hard as F*ing rocks. You look at them and think, oh yeah, come to mama...I want to relax and throw back my cocktails in the comfort of your cushions. In actuality, they're so uncomfortable that you almost debate sitting on the ground instead.

2) Three words: Cash. Only. Bar. I'm sorry but that is CRAP. The last time I was in and handed over my credit card, the server directed me to the cash machine in the back. So, what you're telling me is that I have to get raped with non-ATM fees because you're bar can't come in to the 21st century? No thank you and good day.
author: Julia N.

description:
So I have been to Royal Oak a few times now and I really like it. I do think you need to get there by 10:00 if you want to try and get a seat. Speaking of seats, the place has a few red velvet couches and some big dinning type tables. I think the drinks are a bit expensive, but they do have a nice selection of booze. Getting a drink at the bar can be a bit tough, but if you are lucky enough to get a seat, the cocktail waitress always dose a great job!
*WARNING* cash ONLY bar!!
author: Lisa A.

description:
The reviews of this place may be mediocre, but at least they are consistently mediocre!  I will have to concur with the general sentiment here.  Although this bar has a nice vintage decor with all the plush velour-upholstered couches and chairs and fancy chandelier mood lighting you could want, they blast the music unusually loud - even for a bar - the staff can be rude and alouf, and they only take cash. 

booo to places that only take cash! I'm sick of it!
author: Rick H.

description:
1 star for decor......It has a cozy finish and a very old school english pub feel to it....So Sad...that:
1 Bartender is very rude (don't mean snobby) just rude and unprofessional, and she makes the shitiest drinks...brunette, medium to shortish hair, on week days..please, somebody fire her!
2 The music on the week days is too loud...I can understand it on the wknds.
3 They don't take cards...c'mon folks...this is not a taco truck...on the other hand I might get from taco truck at this point...
So if you're in russian hill...go to some other close by local pubs and bars......Guarantee you'll have a better experience...w/out any BS like Royal Oak....
author: Alex W.

description:
The two stars is for posting your hours as Monday Through Sunday 5pm to 2am when it seems you are closed/open randomly.

I was meeting  colleagues for a drink, and recommended the Royal Oak as a good place to get a few drinks and plan out the evening.

A lot of reviews stated it's often closed, but I figured if they "open" at 5pm, I'll be safe going by around 6:30.

Well, it was closed when we arrived, and  I was embarrassed, and had to scramble for a decent spot to go to and coordinate the others en route to meet us to a new place.

Life won't wait, but adjust your posted schedule accordingly, be considerate if you can't have someone show up to open the place.
author: Kevin G.

description:
Why does this bar smell bad?  It's airy and filled with plants -- you'd think they would absorb the smell with the whole O2/CO2 exchange.  I can't even explain it -- but it really kinda smells like butt.  

As for drinks -- cash only.  Boooo...
author: Mitzi C.

description:
Again, I have no clue how in 2008 a bar can not take cards or just refuses to. 

The bar itself is pretty eclectic, with the glow of red lights and old buttoned couches sprawled everywhere. The chairs and seating arrangements are comfortable and the overall vibe is very mellow. At least on a Sunday night when I visited.

The bartenders were friendly, and the beer selection was standard. I'd be interested in coming back on a Friday or Saturday night, but there wasn't anything too special here.
author: Mike K.

description:
We came here after a looooong day of tailgating and football watching so we were beat.  Funny thing is earlier in the day, my buddy got SOOOOO hammered at our old fraternity house he passed out cold.  Now normally I would say at my age with wiser adage I wouldn't do anything like what we were about to instigate, but he did pass out in a fraternity house, so it was more like his fault than ours.  Well...anyway, we drew a bunch of penises on his face (this was at like 4pm) and he carried them allllllll night long.

While we were at Royal Oak, we met up with some of my friends and they all saw the drawings on his face and laughing discreetly.  All of my friends, strangers at the bar, the bartenders were all grabbing him for pictures.  One point during the night, he turns to me and goes "Man your friends are all sooooo nice!"  "Yeah they are" I replied...hahaha

Finally after last call, they turn the lights on while he was at the bar.  Since the back of the bar and the retaining shelves are all mirrors, he finally discovered we mutilated his face with a sharpie and fiiiiiiinally went and washed them off.  Man, he carried penises on his face for about 10 hours...

Well I guess this is a review about the bar; it's cool, casual, fun.  Not divey but definitely not too shi-shi.  The bartenders are awesome and always say whats up.  I wouldn't recommend starting here cuz this place will definitely blow your hearing out for the rest of the evening.
author: Nico M.

description:
I don't mind cash only establishments because usually it means that it's worth the inconvenience of taking that extra step in going to an ATM or even worse, incurring two different surcharges.  

However, it would be nice to walk into a bar and actually have a bartender know how to make two somewhat common drinks.  Luckily I had been a bartender for a few years to know what the ingredients were for two beverages when the bartender confessed that she didn't know how to make two certain drinks.

A person that tends bar is usually competent behind the bar and this competence usually entails knowledge of alcoholic beverages OTHER than pouring beer.
author: Karen B.

description: Walked into the place last night with a group of friends. Right away a very foul scent of Body Oder was noticed and we looked at each other and wanted to puke. We sat close to the door for air, only reason we stayed because we had 10 minutes to spare and wanted a fast shot....Bartender was not friendly and very hard to believe others were just sitting int here enjoying the foul smell... Another couple walked in and I heard them mention the scent of BO as well and they walked right out... it was disgusting.....Used the bathroom as well and there were towels and piss all over the floor.... Bartender used the bathroom right before me and didn't bother picking the paper towels up... that's a problem......will not be back
author: David J.

description: This is still my favorite bar in the whole city. Stained glass and amazing fancy couches and good music!
author: L B.

description:
I really like this place and I agree with Megan and Michelle on its allure and classic feel. Also (mW), the meanarse bartender is gone (woohoo!) and all we got was great service and a sense of humour (from Maria?)  Disclaimer: it was a weeknight, so I can't say what goes on during the weekend here. 

Nevertheless, the greyhounds are delish, the ambiance relaxed and the old-skool couches super comfy. The decor is funky and green and some of the details feel like something out of a 007 flick.  I'll definitely be back!!
author: I. O.

description:
I've heard a lot of people complain about the Royal Oak in similar ways that they bitch about the City Tavern, the Blue Light, or any handful of douchey Marina bars.

I guess I've been lucky to go to the Royal Oak on off hours. For my money, it's a real good place to have drinks when it's empty. 

The furniture is comfortable and the lighting makes most people seem semi attractive. And they have Chimay on tap.
author: Jason R.

description:
This is not a pick up bar, although I have been picked up here,...and watched others be/do here as well but it's just not one..so if you are stumbling in looking for that scene you will be dissatisfied... 
If you're wandering around with a small group who's having a hard time jumpstarting their own party you will also be dissatisfied....
However if your group is a party within themselves, or you want to catch up with a friend or co-worker, or if you were successfully picked up on (vice versa) at one of the more loud and crowded bars nearby and need a quieter place to well "get to know each other" this place works!
I'm using the dark wood description again- I know I know, fuse that with my definition of Victorianish and Victorian red and throw in a bunch of plants you got yourself the Royal Oak! I like this place I really do... really...
author: Gracie A.

description: "Cash only," the unfriendly bartender barked at me. The couches are comfortable. I'll give the Royal Oak that, but not much more.
author: Miriam W.

description:
The color red has traditionally meant a sign of trouble.  My wife wore a red dress that looked oh so yummy during her bachelorette party years back and from the stories I heard, well lets just say you wouldn't bring it up during Sunday school.  

No doubt the color red makes people take notice whether some girl is wearing it on her tight body, it's a stop sign, a red Ferrari, or a severely injured person.   

Back in college a few buddies and I went to the local bar to pick up some hotties.  I was a complete dork so basically I was a wing man trying to talk up the less attractive birds (or cows might be more appropriate) while my buddies went up to bat hoping to hit a home run.  One time, my friend landed this Ivanka Trump look alike.  Since my friend was obviously thinking with his penis, his strategy was to get her liquored up (original one there huh?).  

So she's sucking down strawberry margaritas like a vacuum cleaner.  I try telling the guy she's clearly way too wasted.  Him thinking with his penis thinks it's a no brainer.  So we end up in said friend's car and lets just say we hear the infamous drawl "uhhhhh I don't feel so good" from this cat.  Next thing my buddy's interior turns from white to red as a sea of half digested strawberry margarita mix finds its way back to earth looking not nearly as good when it first went down.  So the saying goes, red brings trouble.  

The Royal Oak has a very red interior.  It looks cool, seems cool but something is clearly missing.  It's true that the bathroom smelled worse than 10 day old piss and yes it's true the drinks are expensive.   But red is supposed to give you a feeling of naughtiness, trouble, passion ... something to make the heart go bump.  I feel none of these here ... zero excitement.  

Maybe it's the music, the scene, the bathroom, the lifelessness of the bartnender or the DNA infested couches.  Of course in the end it could be I only respond to red dresses being worn by my better half now.
author: Bill P.

description:
This holiday season I elected to stay home and enjoy my beautiful city with peace and quiet... no crowds, no traffic, just a sweet sigh of RELIEF from all the people.

Of course I had to have my cocktails so with a few other friends we decided to throw an impromptu "Ugly Holiday Sweater Polk Street Stumble" (aka pub crawl) a few days before Christmas.

Royal Oak was so much fun- they still have those large comfy couches I remember from years ago, lots of space, dim/red lighting, and extra oxygen from all the plants in there!

Only thing... besides our beers, we didn't like any of the cocktails... our bartenders had a weak hand (HOW could you mess up a vodka soda??). Oh, and that "Cash Only" thing bugs.
author: Nenette Y.

description: On Polk street, the atmosphere was nice, the people were decently dressed up, and prices of the drinks were on par with neighborhood bars. We only hung out for a bit, but while here the crowd was mainly doing their thing. It's predominantly caucasian, so just in case you're looking for an asian crowd, this isn't the place. I felt like I was back in North Carolina when I came here
author: Eric A.

description: Not a bad local bar if you're in the area. Prohibition on tap, funky couches -- relatively standard otherwise.
author: Andy S.

description: New to this place, and came to meet up with friends for drinks. Decor is laced in red velvet chairs and couches, similar to a Victorian style living room set up. Drink prices are very reasonable and service nice, although long wait for drink service preparation. Music level is average, and still able to have conversations, but still need to raise your voice. Restrooms are limited with two stalls and poor lighting, and as for parking/location street and metered parking, so somewhat difficult to find in the later hours of the night.
author: Jackie W.

description:
It's an ok place. Not sure what to write apart from that. I actually like the sofa's and the greenery. It can get really crowded and loud and the drinks are way overpriced but where else can I go and practise my very poor russian with some waitress as I order the next scotch? :)

"Vi iz rassi?", I utter as I lean in towards the waitress who kneels down next to me as I sit on one of those could-smell-better sofas.

"What you say?", she replies and laughs.

"Eh, sorry, thought you had a russian accent", I reply and my mind has already moved on to if I want the 12 or 18 year old mcallan as the last glass of 12 year old was huge and I'm hoping to score the same amount for the 18year old...

"Oh I am", she says and sits down on the sofa next to me and my friend. "I just didn't hear you. What did you say?"

"I said 'Vi iz rassi?'", feeling increasingly uninterested in if she really IS russian at this point. I'm not so why do I really care. We sit in one of those couches that are to the left of the entrance with a view of the street corner but the windows are all fogged up. The people moving outside on the street cast shadows on the windows that are nicely framed by these enormous plants. 

As I finish my drink I smile and ask her if she has any Mcallan 18 and they do. I order one. Neat. Ice is for people who don't appreciate fine scotch. 

I lean back on the couch and my friend leans over and semi-yells in my ear "Did you order for me?"

I'm puzzled and say "They were out"

"Out of what?", she replies. "I didn't tell you what I want"

"Peace on earth, a cure for cancer and the ability to eat anything you want without gaining a pound?"

Never did see her again.
author: Rich S.

description: This place is wack and awful the bartender was a drunk and was dancing like a stripper when we came in, shouldve walked out...all and all this bar is trashy just like the decor, dont waste your time
author: Ashley J.

description:
The Ambiance is very warm and inviting...  its red walls, large oak bar and laid back music make it a chill spot to sip on a drink and catch up with old friends or a date...

The waitress are always hot ...
and the Vibe is chill, not to snoby ..
author: James W.

description:
HA HA !  

This place sells more meat than Molly Stones !!  You walk in and everyone eyeballs you (eye f**ks you) like a glass of water in the sahara.

Come here to get laid, go somewhere else for a drink.
author: Mark B.

description: I have mixed feelings about Polk street on Friday and Sat. nights. Otherwise cool bars become inordinately packed and frantic. Royal Oak, however, is different. Maybe it's because it's a bit further up on Polk, or maybe it's because this place has a super-chill vibe, but it's always a great respite from the hoards at other bars like the Buccaneer, etc. The plants and chandeliers are kitschy and unusual.   The drinks are always strong and the prices are right. I've only had friendly bartenders, and I like the clientele. The only downside is that it is, regrettably, cash only, but if you come prepared you're sure to have a great evening out!
author: Jenni D.

description:
It felt royal, not so oaky.

I would really like to come here again.

The place wasn't too crowded and the drinks weren't out of this world. And they had Chimay on tap.

This place has a fancy feel to it but is by no means fancy. As my bf stated, "It's like going to my Italian grandma's house". Except I'm sure your Italian grandma wouldn't have a bunch of 30 somethings hanging out and drinking all her liquor. 

There were velvet couches, big tables, big windows, nice understated lighting, nice people, and shitty shitty music.
author: Kristina C.

description:
The problem of Royal Oak is their cocktail socks.
I don't know why they can not make decent cocktails.

The furniture setting is old style and nice even it's so uncomfortable to sit more than 30min. But it's all about atmosphere, I can live with it.

Bartender puts her fingers so many time to dig out the ice cubes fell in the cocktail glass is NOT GOOD. 
I don't think it's all the bartender there is that bad. I have to say but I met enough bad ones and I refuse to go back there if I have a choice.

I really don't understand why the place is packed on the weekend.

It's really too bad, because I like their setting. I like their location. 
It's just.... I can't use them.
Haaah....
author: Green Mango Y.

description:
royal classy red themed.....stiff antique sofa 'n' chairs....stiff drinks matching....long stooled bar starting from entrance....plentiful eclectic mixture of seating...seating tightly packed.....a bar/lounge/cafe appearance.....high back dining chairs 'n' table...

a walk along polk...."last call hours".....closing time....royal oak obliged to serve one last drink....two vodka 'n' soda...$twenty total.....no other patrons visible...just another stop for a drink before heading home for the night....
author: Hen A.

description:
The funky old couches are kinda cool, though mostly uncomfortable, the drinks are absurdly overpriced (stick with beer), but it's generally a good place to go for attractive people watching.
The best part are the notes people leave in the drawers.  Have a look, and leave your own.
Best story about these ever - as a joke, we left a friend's phone # as a "for a good time call...".  Our next visit was over a month later.  While in the bar, someone called the #.  This was the one and only time it was called.  Hilarious.
author: Don H.

description:
What keeps me out is that the beer is served Joe-sixpack style:  Way over-chilled and in a frosted glass.
Beer is not supposed to give you an ice headache.
author: helge m.

description:
I will always have fond memories of the Royal Oak, for it is here that I was introduced to the gentleman's game of Liar's Dice.  

Relaxing atmosphere, even on a busy night, and arranged in such a way that sightlines for leering at people, both inside and out, are preserved.
author: Sam M.

description:
It looks promising enough from the outside, but I'm afraid I don't care for:

- The beer
- The staff
- The prices
- The decor
- The patrons

And yes, I've been more than once. Sorry, still don't care for it.
author: Thor E.

description: This place deserves a little more love. All the greenery is quirky, the place is large and not too too noisy. Drinks are stiff.
author: Andrew K.

description: Totally fine place to grab a drink with friends.  Definitely scene-y with lots of young ones, but the drinks aren't too expensive and the decor is kind of fun in a campy sort of way.  The cash-only bar is a bit of a buzz kill.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Nice place to end a crawl, sit back, drink, and talk about things that seem more interesting at the time then when you think back about them later. 
It's redness helps to distinguish it when you're trying to remember where it is. 
The limited beer options MIGHT suck, but that is why I recommend this place as the final stop for your evening. By that time, you're either really flexible with your drink choices or a  wound-up tight-ass who would be better off heading home.
author: Loli L.

description:
love this venue for the chill vibe and the friendly bouncer who sometimes doubles as a bartender when clients are ready to throw ice chips at the one female bartender who goes way beyond the requirement for blond stereotypes.

i'm pretty sure she was coked up on thanksgiving - didn't know one drink from the next, was running in circles attempting to do math in her head while successfully ticking off everyone and ruining their tryptophan turkey highs.

am afraid to go back because of that.   that and the velvet sofas that kept swallowing me whole with their 100 year old squeaky springs and deteriorating cushions.
author: Josie M.

description:
This place gets two stars right off the bat for being one the last remaining "fern" bars in the neighborhood, a style that dominated San Francisco in the late 70s and early 80s. A place you could hide under a fake tree with a group of coked-out disco freaks. Before AIDS. Before all of these American-Arabian wars.

They have some of the hottest-looking bartenders in town - mostly ladies, of ciourse. One more star for that. The prices, however, are steep and the hot bartenders are not too interested in conversation beyond small talk, so repeat business is not necessarily encouraged (i.e., I've never had the bartender buy me a drink - I'm sure the owner has them under a tight leash). Still, once in a while, when you really DON'T want to talk to anybody, you can wind up here and enjoy one hassle-free drink,  enjoying a little bit of the eye candy while stuck in a time zone reminiscent of the Rupert Holmes' "Pina Colada Song" era.
author: Nitram N.

description:
Setting-Red with interesting furniture and lots of plants.
Crowd-young and not so young professionals who seem laid back and unpretentious.
Music-old school pop and hip-pop.  It took me back to middle school.
Drinks-STRONG!  Just the way I like it. *slurp*
author: Vivian H.

description: Loud, epic and fun. The speak easy, Moulin Rouge themed bar is the perfect setting for all things amazing. Give the door man a hug, his massive built hides a sweet heart! Great scene, loved it.
author: Rey G.

description:
Dead during the week.

Too crowded on weekends.

Where's the middle ground?

Even though I live less than a block away, I never come here.
author: Ava S.

description:
I admit this place has a cool atmosphere; that said, their cocktails are weak. 

I live down the street and have given this place a million chances...  the drinks suck every time.
author: Naveen S.

description:
Its amazing how many bars I've been to in San Francisco that seem to be full of tools. I'm not even kidding, this bar seemed like it was full of meatheads and their drunk bimbo "friends".
One particularly ripe strumpet grabbed my girlie's boobs in the restroom, and then tried to play it off with a typical "Its all good!!!"

The drinks were ok but a bit overpriced, and it was a bit slow too, but I think all the tools were busy getting their drink on so they wouldn't notice how rank their dates were.
author: Tom S.

description:
You would never guess this place is CASH ONLY but it is.  Keep that in mind, because we were ill prepared and had to leave after one beverage because we needed cab money!

It's a gorgeous bar with a really romantic setting.  All the light fixtures are stained glass and the overall atmosphere makes you feel like your back in time in a 20s, 30s type of swanky bar.  It was really sexy.

The bathrooms, not so sexy.  I was surprised the bathrooms were kinda gross for how cute the place was.  Hmm, guess you can never tell.

I'd go back again but it was really crowded.  I would probably get there early to secure a cool couch by the window.  We sat at the bar and it wasn't quite as fun
author: Lindsey S.

description:
This place has the potential of being really cool but it's located in Russian Hill that (please correct me if I'm wrong) is basically where all the Alumni's of Sigmi Chi reside.  

Putting my wannabe diverse, cultured, laid back persona aside.  I have to admit that I have enjoyed this place.  If you get here early with a small group of close friends you may enjoy the plants, red - light, cozy couches, and music.

Could be a great place to bring a date for a drink or two.
author: Justin C.

description:
Ok, so I really like the vibe this place. The red hue, vintage (random) sofas/chairs and the tiffany-like lighting makes it feel comfy and cozy. This place would be a super sexy romantic spot, if they spiffied it up and could draw in a sophisticated crowd.

Anyhow, this place plays trance/techno/house music (I truly don't know the difference it all sounds the same to me). It's a cool place to head to if you just want to get out of the house with some friends, sit back people watch and shout at each other bc its so damn loud.
author: melissa g.

description:
A fun little haunt on weekday nights. Really cool interior, feels like an old fashioned bordello. Authentic tifanny lamps, sculptures, red walls and tons of plants. The hand carved bar is quite impressive as well. Seating is open and spacious, big round tables and velvety chairs.

I don't recommend for Friday or Saturday nights, it tends to get filled with fratty Marina douche bags in linen shirts. This bar is at its prime between 8-12 when it's quiet and the kooks are still inside.

They have a good selection of whiskeys and vodkas.
