It's a seductive bar straight out of "Eastern Promises", a quiet place to drink after a nice dinner on Polk St.
author: Andreas T.

description:
Royal Oak is a nice lounge bar, but their cash-only policy is the stupidest thing ever. Why can't you take credit cards? Maybe they were busted for scamming people like that guy on the Sopranos.

Besides that major gripe, I really do like this place. The couches are comfy, everyone seems friendly, and you can drink at your seat from the waitresses. It's sandwiched between Green's and The Buccaneer, and luckily has no TVs, so no douche-bag sport-o r-tards.
author: Joseph T.

description: I walked in this place on Saturday night and wasn't quite sure what this place was. They were playing terrible house music, the people all looked like they belonged own the Jersey Shore, encountered girls doing cocaine right out in the open. This place is disgusting.
author: Christie S.

description:
It all depends what night you go:
During off hours/days such as Monday nights I love this place.  Fun, relaxed "fern bar" atmosphere with cool patrons.  On Thurs, Fri, Sat nights this place is awful.  They put on LOUD club music that's totally out of place and the place becomes packed with obnoxious, egotistical marina people (and I'm from the marina so I feel justified damnit).
author: James B.

description: I love this place and I don"t mind cash only. The bartender chickie with the cuban hat was nice to talk with,  I got  really buzzzzed here for New Years day. It was worth the time.
author: Steb M.

description:
We were recommended to this lounge as we were looking for a place to hang while we waited for a performance at the Red Devil Lounge.

Overall it has a really great atmosphere and is completely geared to you and your entourage to sit, drink, chat and have a good time for as long as you want.

One very appealing aspect is the eclectic ensemble of furniture for you to sit on or at.  Sofas, chairs, large round tables or the bar.  Just come on in, get a drink and chill.

The downside is the drinks are really overpriced, the furniture is a bit cheap and uncomfortable for long sit-downs, no real wine selection - they're really focused on the beer and spirits - and the bar ran out of Kahlua (!?!?) while mixing a drink for me!  Also, don't expect any real service, there was one bartender handling about 20 patrons until a second showed up later in the evening.

The laid-back atmosphere, polite bartender and cool furniture / plant theme are the saving graces here.
author: Sean T.

description:
Gorgeous 'Sunset Boulevard' meets 'Moulin Rouge' decor - lavish antique sofas, stained glass, carved Edwardian end tables, Tiffany lamps, lush ferns and red light bulbs. Well-stocked bar with top-shelf liquors. Convenient location on Polk (and subsequently a few blocks down from my apt.)
So why don't I soak the decadent atmosphere in on a regular basis? Because the music selection does NOT match the decor. Crappy house club trendy pop, every night of the week. And I think the volume knob is broken, turn that DOWN when you have only two people sitting in there! Save it for a dance club. Play some old jazz, classical, maybe even blues. It would be PERFECT. Maybe even once a week? Please? Royal Oak, are you worried that the local hoodlums wouldn't hang around anymore if you didn't play oontz oontz muzak? Never fear- I'll summon an army of over-tipping antiquiphiles who will drink you out of your Campari and Cognac.
author: Andrea Z.

description:
Let me quickly be a broken record... it sucks that they only take cash, the couches are not the most comfortable, and the red glow is slightly oddish.

Besides that, I'm a big fan.  I love the Chimay on tap, the bar tenders are all nice, and the crowd is not too snobby or fratty.  Good place to chill with friends or (attempt to) meet new people.
author: Brady L.

description:
the first time i went there, the crowd was so nice, i had so much fun.  Like a puppy who found a new home.  People were in the late 20's, 30's, very nice looking, no pretentions unlike in the closeby Marina.
Then i went again a few times, to find it empty with older people.
But i keep on trying.
author: Damien J.

description: Don't ever go here! The bartenders are racist. They kicked my friend out for being Asain. This is not acceptable. This bar should be shut down.
author: E H.

description: Royal Oak is one of my new favorite bars in the city. It's sort of a cross between a dive bar and a posh pub. The ambiance is unbeatable - the decor is really cool, kind of an early 20th century feel with heavy wood and Tiffany lamps and there is a nice, cozy couch area that is perfect for a group of friends to sit around and talk. The music is upbeat and fun, although the bar isn't set up for dancing. The people who hang out there seem receptive to talking and socializing - and since I enjoy meeting new people when I go out, this is a big plus. The biggest drawback is that the bar is cash only - there's an ATM by the bathrooms, but if you don't want to pay ATM fees, make sure to bring cash.
author: Randi W.

description:
Repeat after me......

"I will not go to bars on the weekend and expect them not to be crowded and douchy."
"I will not go to bars on the weekend and expect them not to be crowded and douchy."
"I will not go to bars on the weekend and expect them not to be crowded and douchy."
"I will not go to bars on the weekend and expect them not to be crowded and douchy."
"I will not go to bars on the weekend and expect them not to be crowded and douchy."
"I will not go to bars on the weekend and expect them not to be crowded and douchy."
"I will not go to bars on the weekend and expect them not to be crowded and douchy."
"I will not go to bars on the weekend and expect them not to be crowded and douchy."
"I will not go to bars on the weekend and expect them not to be crowded and douchy."
"I will not go to bars on the weekend and expect them not to be crowded and douchy."
"I will not go to bars on the weekend and expect them not to be crowded and douchy."
"I will not go to bars on the weekend and expect them not to be crowded and douchy."

Okay...do I need to tell you what days this place is tolerable? And by tolerable I mean stabbing me in the eye with a cocktail stirrer would be almost as pleasant. 

The drinks are not strong AT ALL and a well drink will cost you $7, just $1 less than the premium stuff. They don't have one of those soda squirty thingies (that is the official term) and when I inquired why, the bartender said it was because they prefer to have drinks that are more "pure". I assume she meant pure soda because there was NO ALCOHOL in my beverage. 

To top it off the chairs they have around their big wood tables are very top heavy, causing them to fall over should you drape your jacket on the back. Perhaps this is to make those wandering by think some inebriated person just knocked a chair over so the drinks must be strong. 

Plus one star for having a decent "cozy" dark wood decor reminiscent of your grandfathers study and for the fact that they actually have more than one stall in the womens restroom.
author: Drue C.

description: I was here on a Tuesday, so have no idea what it's like on the weekends, but I really liked it. It was a good place to go for a few quiet ones, definitely not for dancing or anything like that. I enjoyed the comfy velvet couches and the tiffany lamps. The thing that stood out the most for me, though, was the bartender. She was extremely friendly and knowledgeable, and the drinks were extremely strong. Will definitely be heading back here. PS They do accept credit cards.
author: Sarah F.

description: If you're out with Drunk Girl (we were) who's married (she was) and she insists on hitting on your friend (she did) who is also married (he was) and she's dropping her drinks (she was) with some frequency (all of them), there is no better place than Royal Oak, aka The Fern Bar.
author: Kevin S.

description: Drinks are pretty expensive for their small size and the crowd can be annoying but if you are lucky enough to grab some space on one of the couches up front it can be a decent spot to have a couple of drinks with friends.  Just don't expect to have a conversation without shouting.
author: phil h.

description: To the owners of the Royal Oak: Please clean and air out this stink-hole of a bar. Seriously, the place was great 9 years ago which was probably the last time anyone febreezed the sofas, but now it's just plain nasty. I pointed out a mouse running along the wall to one of the servers last time I was there. She was like "yeah, we know about it" without missing a step. Whoa. Time-out. I know you're not serving food in here, but there has be some kinda health code violation going on. Clean up your act and regain your glory!
author: Steven H.

description:
I have to say when i walked into this place.  I thought wow... everything is so pink.  I was then told i was color blind because everything was red.  Although i still think it was pink.  Anyway this place is cute, with interesting lighting (the pink i was talking about) and very... i want to say it has an era theme, but which era?  I don't know.  This is something i'm not too familiar with.  Marianne said maybe the 30's... i just don't know.  You could say something is from the 70's and i'd be like... really?  But enough with my colorblindness and lack of era knowledge.   

The best part of the night was the girl bartender.  She didn't know how to make the simplest drinks.   When ordering drinks confusion just flooded her face.  So we started off with some beers... not too hard considering we ordered the ones on tap.  However, she did end up spraying beer all over one of our friends.   Then we got to the girly drinks like midori sour.  She got that.  Next, it was my turn and i asked for a sidecar.  Hmmm... "is that like a manhattan but with brandy?"  Ummmm... NO!!  So then she looks it up in this book... and tells me... uhhh we don't have brandy!  So i ordered a vodka martini straight up, which i got for free because she couldn't make me a sidecar.  OK fine she made up for it.   Our second round of drinks, confused the poor girl again.  This time i talked to the guy bartender.  I got another martini but Marianne got a chambord sour.  Now, this drink is pretty simple.  One should know how to make this if bartending is their occupation.  Sadly, the guy asked me if that was just chambord and sweet n sour, which i confirmed.  Instead of him making the drink, the girl bartender was given the task of doing it while he made my martini.   Watching her was priceless as she walked back and forth behind the bar looking for chambord which was sitting in plain view.  It wasn't that she didn't see the bottle but she didn't know what chambord was.  I loved it!  Her face was that of bewilderment.  She had to ask the guy what the chambord bottle looked like after 3 min. of searching.  

The lounge was laid back, not too crowded and was quite comfortable.  Some of the furniture was a little old and felt wobbly.  I was afraid that a few of the chairs wouldn't be able to support me.  I'm not even a cow and i was afraid so that should tell you something.  

Overall it was a cool place, bad furniture, and sad bartenders.  At least i got some strong drinks, but then again how can you make a martini wrong?
author: Aaron G.

description: Cash only and how can you charge $12 for a french martini in a small glass and ask me how to make it?
author: Natalie S.

description: This bar has been there forever and its funny to hear people call it "un-San Francisco." It's penultimate San Francisco, at least from a bygone era. But I won't fuddy duddy about it any more. We used to like to go there because you could have a quiet drink, but went last night and it was SUPER loud with a bouncer outside the door and pounding music. It was freezing and I wanted an irish coffee or hot drink of some kind but they had nothing along those lines. I know times change, but whoever has taken it over is probably going to further change the ambiance; not necessarily a bad thing but arent' there enough noisy bars on Polk?.
author: Roxmarie M.

description: Non-pretentious place to chill.  Especially if you have the desire to cuddle with your date on the vintage couches.  Cool stained-glass all around, and a helpful bartender make this place a-ok in my book.
author: Kiki G.

description:
..:11: 15pm PST:..

*giggles* (FYI: i giggle when I'm buzzed) 

i have a bad // good habit of checking my emails (i have more than 1, and my crackberry only takes in my gmail) every night before i go to bed, and at times, i tend to drift away in a moment of reflection ... AND NOW, ever since yelp came into my life, i seem to update on a daily basis since i go out every day... 

note: i write for my own personal use so i can keep track of where i've been to and my experience so i know what to look out for or give other people the head's up.

Amelie vs. Royal Oak... Royal Oak vs. Amelie... Decisions... Had to drift away from the wine for a bit ... :D

i like this place, i really do ... it's simply a place i'd prolly run away to when i need a fix of the marina scene, but not in the marina ... in fact, i feel like i can convince more people to come to royal oak vs the marina since we all know what people think of the marina ... it KINDA had the marina feel, but not really... i really like the fact how it's just up the street from me...well, kinda, passed van ness that is... def does not have the pretentious vibe ... the crowd was quite friendly ... low key, chill, comfortable setting.

overall, it's very SF to me, how everything inside is super victorian ... 
the interior kinda reminded me of balboa cafe, mebe it's all the wood ... the whole redness, yes, the decor, nice... very nice ... i really liked how there were so many plants, it's just got this homey kick to it...scattered with tiffany lamps ...

this would make a decent place to bring a date for a drink or two... i'd def say it's romantic, but on a Thursday evening, you're on your own there since we got these crazy kiddies in one corner ... it's reallll chill, and the sofas are extremely comfy.

TIP: cash only... which truly sucks ...

*yawn* me sleepy... bed time for me...

night yelpers!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Really nice place. Friendly bartending. Great Victorian decor. Came here before Halloween in a quasi-Victorian trench coat and took a bunch of awesome photos along with my blue moon beer.
author: Aaron S.

description: I love going to the Royal Oak whenever I can. It is an awesome bar and I consistently have a good night here every time I come.  It's a great bar to bring a group of friends or a date since there are ample tables and cozy couches to lounge on, but it is also a fun place just to come with a couple people to mingle and have fun since there are usually pretty girls around and a nice crowd in general.  The decor is really cool too and makes me feel like I'm in a jungle, and the lighting provides a nice ambiance as well. It's got a classy feel too it, but not so much that it is stuck up or snobby.
author: James M.

description:
a funky cool bar i'd always passed by and never really checked out until recently.  maybe it has something to do with the fact that it DOES kinda look like an antique store from the outside like the bartender said.

came for a quick drink before dinner plans and the interior seemed really interesting.  the lighting was dim, but not too too dark and there were these really loungey tables and sofas/chairs set up all through out the place.  when i got there, there was a woman reading a book at the bar, the bartender chatting to two friendly cops (is that a contradiction in terms?) and two other smallish groups hanging out.  place seemed to have a very mellow vibe.  definitely thought i'd go back sometime during the work week with friends for drinks.
author: Bird B.

description: One word describes this bar. Attitude. I'm a halfway attractive waitress, now get out of my way. I'm a bartender with a low cut shirt, now what the hell do you want? I want to leave and not come back to this place. Throw in a few random, really drunk boners, some expensive drinks and you have a recipe for me despising this place. It's too bad, because from what I remember their Irish coffees were good but the coffee machine was broken this particular night.
author: Michael E.

description: Fantastic place to get a drink with a friend on a thursday.  The velvet couches are oh-so-comfortable, drinks are good, and its not too crowded.   Probably not the top of your list if you like to dance on tables though.
author: Sloane R.

description: Go for it, put on that stripe shirt, pop that collar, do up the hair, and head to Royal Oak.  Those looking for something "different" won't find it here,  unless prior experiences have taken place entirely in the Marina.  Nevertheless, the bartenders serve good drinks, and quickly, and there are some decent couches and tables to sit with your friends...although talking over the bizarrely loud music may prove a bit difficult.
author: Jason C.

description:
One star for the fact that I can write a bad review with facts to back it up!  Drinks are overpriced, not tasty, and I usually end up spilling it before I can get away from the starving snobs at the bar.  I can never use the bathroom, because...
A - there are a couple girls doing their lines and lock the rest of us out and force us to master the art of "not breaking the seal."
B - I am stopped before I am able to walk in the restroom with a guy half my size and offering to take me up into the "fern treehouse" for some fun....and won't take no for answer so I end up leaving the place.
C - I get knocked out by a falling branch that has not been dusted since the 70's "Fern Bar."
As if this is not enough by my fourth visit to never return, a 22 year old has a cougar on each arm, and throws up on the floor without anyone noticing.
Thanks, but I will stay home with the cat, drink a bottle of wine, and watch him throw up hair balls.  Cheers!
author: Lulu B.

description:
this place has potential, i gave it that much from the moment i walked through the door but it's a dump, sadly.

first of all, it's cash only, which in my humble opinion is the dumbest thing a bar can do to itself.  don't you want your patrons to drink their faces off so they're incoherent and buy even more drinks?  how do you expect them to do that if it's cash only?  but i guess perhaps you're looking out for us and helping us avoid a DUI?

second of all, they have like 2 beers on tap...boring!

third of all, which bar nowadays doesn't have a wet bar?  it was a huge turn off when i see your bartender (point #4) opening bottles of soda and juice.  what a waste of bar space.

fourth and last of all, this place has the most ANNOYING bartender (i went on a thursday night).  if i or my friends wanted another drink, we'll tell you.  don't come over and try to act..."cute" (?) and ask what we'll have next and offer shots.  like that's just trying too hard.  i might've given you credit for trying the first time you asked, but by the 8th time, i just wanted to leave...oh, wait...i did!

p.s.  maybe it's not sanitary for the bartender to be wearing flip flops during her shift.
author: Sally T.

description: Good Atmosphere, good music, Good Selection of drinks. What more do you need? Been going there for years and it has been consistently exceeding my expectations. Drop by and check it out.
author: John G.

description: What a chill bar should be.  Dark, tons of group seating, full bar with bar tenders willing to make you any drink you could imagine.  The bathrooms are a warzone and smell terrible.  Music has always been mashup mixes the owner put together.  It's a good place to end the night.
author: Sean M.

description: I like this bar.  It's a little kooky, very red, a bit old fashioned- but still fun.  The bartender is really nice there.  They make good dirty martinis, and it's quiet enough to talk to people inside.  What I like about this bar is that every time I've gone, there is available seating.  It's nice to just lounge there and relax with friends.  To me, it's a very un-San Francisco type bar, which is a good thing every once in a while.  Good place to come for a night cap.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Pros: 
-you can ask the bartender for dice for a game of liars poker
-lots of couches and tables, which is perfectly conducive to hanging with a group
-good mix of diff types of people

Cons:
-this might be a pro for some, but I don't like all the overgrown huge house plants everywhere.  I feel like I'm at someone's grandmother's house (minus the cats).  It kind of makes the bar feel dark and unclean.
author: LT B.

description: The Royal Oak is my favorite bar in San Francisco to get a drink.  The staff is always friendly, the drinks are solid and the scene is fun.  Its a great location for people to meet up beforehand and even spend the entire night.  I'd highly recommend it on weeknights (great for dates), weekends and on special occassions like New Years.
author: Josh W.

description: I had the most fun here out of my Big Foot and Bar Johnny stops. Mainly because my friend was holding up the plant that was lingering over his head and it was pretty damn funny! I'm not sure I understood the layout. It almost seems as though they need to move the tables out of the way as the night gets later because there isn't a whole lot of room to stand. I felt like I was in a fire drill as I made my way to the other side of the bar to chat it up with some friends. There had to of been at least three tables blocking my entrance, slightly annoying! On the flip side, it could have been worse. You can carry a conversation here and it was pretty chill.
author: Jen B.

description: The Royal Oak is one of the most unique and awesome bars in SF. I love this bar because it will satisfy both those who want to lounge as well as those that want a social scene because there is ample seating with plush furniture to sit in and also lots of people standing by the bar if you want to drink and mingle with the locals. Royal Oak is a fun place and if you are in the neighborhood I suggest you stop by.
author: ben T.

description: Each time I've gone to the Royal Oak it felt as if I was in a sauna.  I mean you can feel the heat and steam as soon as you walk in.  Other than that, the place is decent.  Funny decor.  Plants everywhere and burgundy velour seat covers, if I remember correctly. This place is good to bring a few of your friends and sit around and people watch and talk.  It's not too loud, and there are a lot of seats, if you get there in time to snag some. Bartenders are pretty nice, but drinks are a little questionable and not cheap either.  It's not that bad, but there are tons of other places in the city.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Was there last night with a large group of people. I like this place mostly because there are lots of places to sit and you can have a conversation without screaming. I wasn't drinking last night, but looking at my friends, the drinks seemed pretty strong. I'd go again.
author: kristen v.

description: One of the best bars in SF.   Good crowd, but not very crowded.  The place has lots of comfortable seating and a good bar.  Great to come with a group of friends or a date while also people watching.  Beer is reasonable, bartender can make a good drink.  Not too dark or noisy either.   Solid place.
author: John W.

description: Cool decor, but can only go with a group of friends and even then it's hard to hear each other.  They don't take credit cards either (at least at the bar).  Who doesn't take them???
author: Shawn S.

description: Look, I like a place with old couches, it's my thing.  I also like plants.  Unfortunately, for Royal Oak, I use debit cards and don't like carrying cash.  Despite knowing this, every time I stop by I have little to no cash, have to leave and go to the ATM and by the time I get back I'm pissed that I had to leave for cash and decide to go somewhere else.  This review is far more about me than it is Royal Oak.
author: Eric C.

description: This place is a royal joke. The bartender last Friday night inspired my first ever review on Yelp. She had the WORST attitude I have ever come across. I took one sip of a rum and coke that I just paid for which was gross and I politely asked if I could swap it for something else instead. She just threw away the drink and walked off. After realizing she wasn't coming back (and it wasn't cos she was busy cos there was 2 other people in the whole bar) she told me I couldn't have an alternative drink because she poured it right and that I should have ordered something I liked. She was the rudest, bitchiest most unprofessional bartender EVER. She should be FIRED!!! I will never step foot inside here again.
author: c m.

description: Intimate setting with lots of very cool chairs and scenery to make conversation with.   Avoid if you are trying to meet people, but great last call spot with a group of friends.
author: Eric W.

description: "Dirtier... I like em really dirty.... nope still not dirty enough." This was me trying to explain to the bartender how I like my dirty martinis. It was not the best one I have ever had, but after a few olive juice additions by the bartender, it was definitely drinkable. The atmosphere is amusing here with the shabby/chic couches and faux tiffany lamps and it is a decent place to sit with friends. However, they were playing house music in the bar.... I guess I was confused in thinking this was a lounge, not a dance club. Also cash only... boo.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
the 2 stars are for this bar being literally within 20 feet of my apartment. and the decor is interesting -- like you're great-grandfather's study in a dimly-lit tropical jungle. 
however, i ordered a tom collins and the bartender made it with bourbon and collins mix instead of gin. i mentioned it, and she had to ask me what was supposed to be in a collins ... yikes. she made me another (correctly?) and i can't say it was much better. overpriced for cheap-tasting drinks.
author: Cayla W.

description: Good to note that this place is cash only. It's not that fun, although I love the couches and decor...and it gets so packed on the weekends that you cannot walk around at all, kinda claustrophobic.
author: Barbara A.

description: I'm a sucker for the decor of this place, the old chairs and plants and dustiness and spaciousness.
author: L C.

description: This is just an attempt to bring up the Yelp average on this place which is my favorite along Polk street.  Yes the couches may be a little grungy but I'd rather sit on a semi grungy couch surrounded by lots of greenery than jostling shoulder to shouler in a place like Buccaneer.  The cash-only thing can get a little annoying especially since it's easy to order several rounds once you're situated in a cozy corner, but overall a great place.
author: Helen C.

description:
The lighting--the awful, awful, terrible lighting.  I don't know what it is, or if it's just me, but the place glows red.  It's the pyric fluorescence cast off by Inferno--not unbearably hot, but not entirely flattering, either.

Furthermore, "the drinks are weak" is not usually a complaint I care to voice, but at the Royal Oak, it's a real and consistent problem--especially considering the higher-than-average price of a vodka soda.
author: Hannah J.

description: NOW I know where the red fern grows!  Jesus, bring a machete with you.
author: Marcus C.

description: Probably one of the best lounges in the city though their drinks are a little pricey. The place makes me fantasize about old English men smoking cigars and drinking brandy in private clubs back in the early 1900s. It is a great place to stop by while bar hopping on Polk St when your dogs are barking and you want to sit for a while before getting back out there. And for the ultra lazy, they even have a waitress that will take drink orders and you don't even have to get up to get your drinks. I agree that the crowd is lame but I wouldn't recommend the place if your going to hit on people. More of a sit around with your friends kind of place.
author: Jenny C.

description: A comfortable, overpriced, low key fern bar.  That pretty much sums this place up.  Some friends wanted to meet here last night, and even though this isn't my kind of bar I decided to tag along anyway.  So I get there with another friend, walk up to the bar, and order a Hendricks and tonic for myself and my friend, handing a $20 to the attractive female bartender in the process.  I get back two drinks and no change.  It's at this point that I discover that this place is charging $10 for a gin & tonic!  I'm sorry, but this joint is nowhere NEAR cool enough to charge that for a drink, hot bartender or no.  It'd be a decent bar were the drink prices lower, but even then it wouldn't be anything worth seeking out.   So basically, there's nothing to see here folks, please move along.
author: Joshua W.

description: I was there early on a Thursday evening and thoroughly enjoyed myself.  The decor is very cozy, Victorian and romantic.  The noise level is a dull roar; perfect for conversation, but not so quiet that you're afraid the people near you will overhear things they shouldn't be privy to.
author: Beth G.

description: Lots of fake foliage, red decor, very hot.  I went last night and it was packed. They need an air conditioner or something because I felt like I had entered a steam room when I walked in off the street.  By the time we were able to find seating, I had adjusted to the heat so it was cool.  I was with fun people so it ended up being a good time.  I give it a 3 because the cash only thing is annoying.
author: Seong P.

description: I like this bar a lot. Every year my group of friends gets together on a Thursday in December to have a Christmas drink (or 7) together before everyone leaves town for the holidays, so the Oak holds a special place amongst us. Otherwise we don't get down here all that often but everytime we do I wonder why we don't come more often. Really like the decor, red lighting and tons of plants, very cozy. Major drawback is that it is cash only. Major plus is lots of comfy seating, couches, chairs, etc., for if you're just catching up with folks.
author: Sarah R.

description: Drinks here will cost you an arm and a leg, so try to rest those appendages in one of the plush velvet couches before you head over to the bar. I'm a sucker for lounges and I kind of liked the whole red velvet theme with ferns (not oaks!) scattered all over the place. This was my group's last Polk St barhopping destination so it wasn't that crowded, which was great. However, I can imagine this place getting really annoying when packed.
author: Natalie T.

description:
the husband likes to call this place the royal joke. 
he's so clever.

we actually had our first date here, so i will always have a soft spot in my heart for it. but i agree with what most others say about it. i think they overcharge for weak drinks, and not so good wine. the staff isn't very nice, and it can get way too crowded with assholes from the marina--stay in your own neighborhood wontcha? 

i do like the couchy atmosphere tho and it's not bad if you go early to get a seat, drink beer, and happen to have cash on you.
author: rachel p.

description: So this place is not somewhere I am trying to go again..... I went on a Friday and it is not a spot to chill. If your willing to spring for weak ass pricey drinks then go ahead and get slamboned, But on a week night, with a few friends, for a casual but expensive drinks then go ahead, but be prepared to have an average time. The ferns inside are cool, the red is cool until you realize that this place is NOT cool, then you leave after one drink.
author: peter v.

description: I have a love hate relationship with this bar. Loved it for its chitzy decor (velvet couches, tiffany-style lamps, and foliage aplenty), then hated it for the lame crowd it tends to draw, and now am loving it again because of the friendly bartender who we met Sunday night.  My friend and I just wanted a place to have some coffee and all the local coffee shops on Polk St. close by 11 pm. The awsome bartender not only didn't give us attitude when we sat at the bar to just have coffee, but she served it in a cognac glass with sugarcubes, and spent a good amount of time chatting with us. Can't beat that!
author: shoba d.

description: Expensive, boring, and rude workers.  You have entered the category of "worst San Francisco bars" that is being championed by Kells
author: Adam O.

description: I love this bar. Chimay in the special glass. Beautiful people. Great vibe...NOT TOO CROWDED. I love this bar.
author: Sherie R.

description: It's never been crowded here, but I've also only been here after midnight and it was pretty chill. I could put my feet up on those fancy replica velvet couches and admire the replica Tiffany lamps whilest sipping a nice refreshing Bass & Cider (they f*cked up my Snake Bite)?!?! I guess its more of a "bring your own friends to talk to place."
author: Charm N.

description: Pretty chill place. It's a bar with a lot of mismatched vintage furniture to lounge on. The chairs and couches are actually in surprisingly good condition considering it's a bar. I love the decor - sure is a getaway from the urban cityscape. Everybody was pretty friendly, and this place makes a good spot to hang out with some friends. Not really a place to mingle with strangers the way it is set up. Oh yea, and it's cash only...
author: Jon N.

description:
cool atmosphere... good drinks
def worth checking out if you are in the area
polk street's got a lot
author: Scott K.

description: Been here in the past and remembered it being a bar with lots of ferns and plants and overgrown trees?! I guess they did some slight renovation and the place seemed a lil less congested. Best to secure a corner or seating area otherwise, you get bumped around in the bar area. Casual chill-out place, reminds me of Rainforest Cafe with all these luscious greenery altho without the owl hoots and animal noises and ok, they don't serve food.
author: Yan M.

description: I have the feeling that when they turn on the lights in this place it seems mighty shabby. However, it has a certain charm bathed in red light. It's a mecca for Russian Hill yuppies so be prepared for lots of guys congratulating each other loudly over some conquest and girls teetering by yabbering on cell phones.
author: Cathy T.

description:
meh... i like the redness. it reminds me of my favorite santa cruz bar the redroom. the couches were comfy too. boo's to being cash only (at least thats what we were told) and sitting on couches where couples decided to sit right across from you and basically get it on right there. i'm all about the loving, but not right in front of my face, in public!!

the drinks were decent, people were eh. maybe will return and try another nite.
author: Jessica B.

description: This place is really strange....just moved in nearby and not a big fan of the polk street scene, but it was a monday night and we just wanted to grab a few drinks somewhere nearby.  This place was packed on the weekend, but empty on monday (obviously), so the bartender was training someone new, and making random recommendations as they didnt have a drink menu (i'm a picky drinker).  i said i like vodka, so she made us some random shit that tasted awful, and we felt bad to say both the drinks were god awful, so pretty much just paid $8 each plus tips (cash only) for drinks we left untouched.  The plant decor is kind of cute, but more just seems to be covering a nastier, tacky backdrop.  Also, it resembles a place near my house in the west village in nyc, russian bartenders and the same style decor (yet more $$ and crappier drinks)
author: Danielle J.

description: Decent bar with a nice ambiance. Lots of wood and plants.
author: Nicolas H.

description: Seriously, get a credit card machine.  Be prepared to pay "cash only".  Truly annoying.  Getting past the credit card issue, I would recommned a visit.  I like the interior and the crowd is pretty friendly.  But they need to start taking credit cards.
author: Tom C.

description: I enjoy the Royal Oak for a variety or reasons ranging from how comfortable it is inside, the Chimay on tap and the Marina contingency constituting of the minority.  The one thing I don't like is that it's a cash only bar, which is pretty annoying.  Anyway, it makes for a great night.  I usually do dinner @ Lemongrass, go to Royal Oak and then end the night at Tonic.
author: Jonathan V.

description: SO I use to go drink here before baby and loved the mellow vibe as well as the ambiance.  A couple times I went out after baby I came here for some drinks and girlfriend time.  Very relaxing and great place to throw a couple back or 3 or 4..heehee!  The only problem is parking SUCKS!
author: Michelle M.

description:
now this is my kind of bar.   to be honest, i've rarely scoped the crowd.  i'm happily attached, so the social scene is less important to me than the ambience when i'm out for a drink.  i enjoy a rowdy, friendly place as much as the next girl.  and this isn't where i'd go if i wanted to make new friends...

but it's down the street from my house, clean, has comfortable seating, and is rarely outrageously packed.  it's the antithesis of beauty bar, which i got dragged to one night after a blissful cocktail at the royal oak.  i realized, despite loving the restaurants and prices in the mission, i prefer the comforts of russian hill.  i guess that settles it- i'm not a hipster and i'm also no longer in my early 20's.
author: nicole l.

description: Expennnnnnsive ($7 for a Chimay--okay, Chimay is expensive in general), very girly (not a knock), very reddish, very Victorian(?) with incense burning and chock full of Tiffany lamps. It is cozy for sure though. But...meh.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Like many others, I am quite confused that this place doesn't take cards.  The only other time I have ever gone into a bar that didn't accept credit cards was when I went to one's opening night and their credit card system wasn't working yet.

My friends and I came in here after we had just left the Bigfoot Lodge and saw that it didn't look too crowded.  The setting here was pretty relaxing, but I guess I just tend to feel comfortable in bars that have that tinted red lighting.  The music was quite an interesting mix where one song would be 2pac only to be followed by Sublime.  Pretty nice if I must say so myself.

All in all, pretty normal bar that one can still have a nice drink at with good friends, granted you carry cash.  If you're into the frat party like bar setting, this might not be for you as I noticed the clientele mostly consisted of the older, possibly more accomplished crowd.
author: Joel J.

description: I came here on a Friday night around 11pm, and it wasn't that busy.  The place has nice decor, and there's plenty of seating.  But the drink was pretty lousy.  We paid $8 each for our martini, and it was practically water.  Barely any taste of alcohol, or fruit for that matter.
author: Mon L.

description: So classic, old school San Francisco-- with the Tiffany lamps, velvet couches and ferns.  I didn't feel that it was dirty/stinky like some reviewers said, but maybe they cleaned it.  I liked that it wasn't very crowded on a Saturday night, and it was entertaining to watch the scene from a couch in the corner.  Yes, it's expensive, but the bartender sure can make a mean Rusty Nail...and Manhattan.
author: Vivien W.

description: Gotta love that jungle atmosphere!  The crowd is a bit lame (everyone kind of looks EXACTLY the same), but the plethera of plants from the floor to the ceiling make this small bar pretty darn fun to hang out in with some friends.  And so do all the cool mirrors, lamps, and the furniture... all night I wanted to walk out the back door with one of their huge old-school red velvet sofas.  Oh yeah, and the drinks were pretty good too.
author: Stephanie P.

description: This is a continuation of the concept of a "fern" bar from the 1970s where non Californians came out to breed with as many new partners as possible to Californicate California with mega mansions, techno billionaires with Attention deficit, 4 wheel drive vehicles for city driving, therefore creating an overabundance of GapKids stores and South of Border nannies that spend more time with Californicated f**k ups in Phoenix House's Kindergarden classroom.
author: miriam b.

description: this place is great depending on the evening. Weekends we stay clear as it's a haven for drunken fratmarina types but on the weeknights it's quiet and comfortable. The atmosphere is nice for a couple of after dinner drinks.
author: Ariana M.

description: nice bar.  good ratio of guys so if you're a single girl this place isn't too bad. Nice decor.  A bit crowded.  Probably would go back.
author: Kelly L.

description: I like the excessive indoor foliage, but the crowd was very college, which is cool if you're in college. But I'm not.
author: Michelle O.

description: Great neighborhood bar!  Love coming here for a night when I feel like going out, but don't want to get too crazy.  Perfect for a Friday-after a long day's work.  Royal Oak has a lounge type setting with vintage decor, dim lighting and strong drinks :)
author: Audrey G.

description:
YYYYAAAAWWWWNNN.

Want to go somewhere trendy for a drink?
This place is lame, try another more 'happening' spot.

Want to go somwhere relaxing and laid-back?
Forget it. This place is snobby.

Want to go somewhere memorable?
Try another Polk St. bar...Royal Oak is lame.
author: Nicole R.

description: Can we say Ambiance?  I really feel like they should change the name to, "In this lighting, anyone could get laid!"  Drinks are a little over priced for what you get, but this bar is totally worth checking out.
author: Jodi P.

description: Nice seating areas but the drinks are overpriced and so-so. My friend has a glass of stale wine that was too awful to finish after one sip. I was stunned the place wouldn't take credit cards (based on the price of the drinks and the seemingly nice decor). Rex Cafe was a much better stop along this street.
author: Everso T.

description:
This is a great alternative to the Fillmore triangle scene, especially if you are already a few drinks into your evening.  The music is loud but at that point you are singing loudly as well.  So, it's ok.  Try and get there in time to grab a table with friends.  

Biggest drawback is the sometimes rude staff and the fact they only take cash.  Fun stop on a Saturday night though.
author: Robert D.

description: Bar offers comfy seating and real chill surroundings. If you are looking for a place to get a couple drinks and relax with some of your buds, this is a good place. Don't expect to make a CRAZY night out of a trip to the Royal Oak because prices and music volume can make extended stays a big tough at times. Usually the music is good, but it can be a bit tough to hear someone across one of their round tables over the tunes. I wish I chilled down there more, because the location offers pretty good people watching in early evenings.
author: Eric W.

description: They got a credit card machine YAY!   This was the one thing preventing it from being the best place on Polk.  The music is an awesome mix that you always find yourself singing along with.  The bartenders are super friendly I asked the girl to make me something good and she created a wonderful drink for me.   Tons of beautiful people and a classy atmosphere.  Now that they accept credit cards its a done deal.
author: Analise Z.

description: nice roomy bar.  i really hate cash only bars though but this one was rather cheap.  people were friendly, especially the bartenders.  wasnt too crowded which is always a plus.  i like to be able to order a drink without getting an elbow to the face.
author: Tiffany L.

description: the decor and scent remind me of my dead great-aunt's little berkeley nest, including that one couch she'd bought during the mcarthy era that has the busted spring that rides up into your crevasse.  you know what I'm talking about.  convenient spot to wait out delayed reservations at any of a number of nice polk street restaurants though.
author: Kosuke I.

description: I really like this place. It's got good decor (red lamps, couches, big round tables, Tiffany lamps) but it's kind of offset by the clientele. Walk in for happy hour and you'll find failed aging AA members mixed with white collar jocks. On the weekends, it's jam packed with typical Russian Hill folk, and is a nice medium between Tonic to the North and Shanghai Kelly's to the South.
author: Jenna F.

description: i'm with meagan.  well, i didn't grow up here and i rarely get to the mission because i'm quite occupied with all that the 'north' has to offer, but i love this place too.
author: George K.

description: The decor of this place it really cool. I did not go in on a weekend night so I can't comment on the crowd. The staff was nice. Definitely recommended for a drink or two. The interior reminds me of National Mechanics in Philadelphia but without the cool science stuff.
author: dc h.

description: I used to love this place to have a quiet drink, I have been going there for a long time. Recently, I met my friends there on a Wednesday ningt around 11 pm. We all work in the restaurant business, and know about service. I don't know what happen to that bar but is going down the hill. That night there were two female bartenders, working you can tell they were flying higher than a kyte. I definetely will not go back there and I will tell everybody not to go there, I used to send people there from the restaurant that I work from but not any more. I was mad and dissapointed with the owner and workers. Don't wast your moner there there are plenty of better bars to have fun.
author: Carlos O.
